issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: The public reaction has not been overblown, if anything it is severely muted.  Recent confrontations are simply making visible issues that have existed for a very long time. There are real issues between police and the communities they serve that are only being addressed because of the attention being paid through Black Lives Matter and other protests. This is how things improve, even if it is hard and difficult to discuss.
message1: The public show the correct reaction to this issue. Their reaction are not overblown. Now things are improving and it should be improved. thousands of minorities lost their life without doing something wrong.now they shows their reaction and its right to show.
message2: It is true that killings of minorities have happened throughout American History, but it is not currently an issue today. There have been a few cases of cops not handling minorities correctly, but there are also cases of cops not handling whites correctly as well. With all the cops and arrests and stops made throughout the country, there are only a small handful of questionable actions by police. If it was a more widespread issue, we would see a lot more videos uploaded to social media.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: While I am supportive of an increase in representation of women in math, sciences, and engineering, I do not believe the best method of achieving this is to give blanket priority to female graduates over male graduates. There is no doubt that women have historically been under-represented in fields such as math and engineering, however by giving women graduates a priority over men simply because of the fact they are women could lead to less-talented candidates entering the field. I believe a better method would be to simply look at the resume/qualifications of the candidate and choose based off of who is more qualified, therefore leading to a "blind" and more objective hiring process.
message1: I also agree that a "blind" hiring practice is how I would like to see companies making their choices. We should not have to consider gender or race when it comes to hiring. I do feel like equity needs to be pushed though. If we see a company is leaning heavily on white male employees then they need to make some more equitable hires.
message2: I agree that qualified men might be overlooked if women are given an advantage and I would agree if it could actually be "blind" meaning that there is no indication of the sex of the candidate. I would then truly believe the best candidate was offered the job. Otherwise, there are implicit biases that people have when hiring women and they need to be addressed.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: As a woman in STEM, my primary consideration is feeling that I have a fair shot at any position that a man has. I don't expect any preferential treatment or gender-based affirmative action policies to compensate for past gender discrimination in STEM, though. There's a perception in some workplaces with these policies that women were only hired to fill a quota, perpetuating the gender divide. I wouldn't want there to be any doubts about my suitability for the position due to my merit, rather than my gender. Of course, people who hire for STEM positions may have unconscious (or conscious) gender biases, but I think that having a diverse hiring panel would be a better policy than implementing gender quotas.
message1: I would say something along the lines of, "I can see your point, having a woman be hired over a man, due to past discrimination, would fuel the notion that women aren't as smart, and her hire would be diminished. I don't really know how we would get more women in the position to hire, if there's a preexisting gender gap in the higher ups, and potential bias, be that conscious or not." I would then ask her how she thinks we should solve the potential bias when hiring.
message2: You raise a good point about the need for a diverse hiring panel. Even though this would help in getting more women hired into stem, ingherent bias may stlll be present both in male and female panel members that skews favor towards hiring men. For this reason, I feel a diverse hiring panel AND quotas towards hiring women into STEM are important.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: I completely disagree with this statement. First, reporting about the loss of a life is never overblown. Second we know, and have seen through body cameras and cell phone video, that there is a problem with the way law enforcement interacts with people of color. In fact, people of color are more likely to experience excessive use of force than their white counterparts. This is even true in similar instances. This is not to say that all law enforcement is bad. In fact most law enforcement is here to serve and protect. However, it does point to cultural issues within the institution that must be addressed to restore trust between the groups.
message1: I agree that systematic changes need to be made, but so far there have been none I've heard that would result in a solution to this issue. The reason minorities are the unfortunate victims in these circumstances is simply because more police are assigned to neighborhoods which have high crime, and they tend to be populated by minorities. I also don't agree with the rioting and looting that the US experienced in 2020 and other times in history. One problem is too many guns are on the streets, but with 3-D gun printing capability now in existence, I don't see a solution to that problem either.
message2: I believe that the media has greatly overinflated these stories to get ratings and clicks. I agree with you that there are a few instances where police have not had proper training and we must ensure that this is fixed moving forward. However, it is imperative that we see through the attempts to further divide us by picking and choosing stories. We should work towards bringing our communities together as well as giving law enforcement the training it needs.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: Women have been historically underrepresented in the fields of math, science and engineering. message1: While I agree that women have been historically represented in STEM fields, I think there are better ways to increase representation. message2: I agree that women have been historically underrepresented in the fields of Math, science, and engineering. This is a problem that we should strive to correct by not discriminating based on gender. I believe that giving women priority in hiring decisions would be step backward because we would still be discriminating based on gender. The only way to correct historical injustice is to no longer follow the same practices.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.

message2: I understand the point taken, but we are a lawful society, and our legal system is based on innocence until proven guilty. issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: I disagree with this statement for a few reasons. The public reaction has had the benefit of forcing the issues of police misconduct which generations of Americans have experienced with no justice or protection to the forefront of public policy in the country.  Without public pressure and a serious acknowedgement of unqeual protection under the law , these crimes against minority communities would continue to be swept under the rug. Also, if the situations were not broadcast in everyone's living rooms, the general majority public who many times have no experience with these injustices, nor knowlege of how  injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere will feel like they dont have a vested interest in developing solutions to the core issues that cause crime (i.e. lack of economic development, race, community distrust etc). If the instances of police brutality and incarceration were being perpetuated on the majority class there would be no end to the public confrontation.
message1: That's just it, the instances of police brutality and incarceration ARE being perpetuated on the majority class, they just are not reported on at the same rate, nor are they headlines on TV and print news every time. The outrage is being stoked by groups who are trying to make money off of the trials and tribulations of certain groups, all of the information about BLM that has come to light in the past year shows. Are there horrible police officers out there? Of course there are. Just like there are horrible people in every work environment. But we don't normally blame a whole profession for a few people's actions. For instance, every year there are nurses that kill patients, either through negligence or outright on purpose. But, we do not, as a society, say that all nurses are bad and out to kill patients. Also, lets look at all of the area where police forces have been parried down and down. All of those areas have massively increased crime and violent crime over the past 3 years. We were told that getting rid of so many police would lessen crime, and yet we see the complete opposite.
message2: While there's no denying that there have been some blatantly WRONG and disgusting actions taken by police in some cases, burning down cities, looting, having a free-for-all on crime is beyond an "overblown reaction." And this isn't just a minority issue, I'm tired of people acting like the same things don't happen to white suspects who aren't cooperating with police, as well. People should just follow police instruction instead of resisting and arguing, and do the resisting and arguing in court, and things like this would happen drastically less often.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.

It has focused almost exclusively on the officer's actions and ignored the fact that nothing detrimental would have occurred had the suspect complied with the officer's orders. Another overreaction is in the public's call for an immediate termination or filing of criminal charges against an officer when there has not been adequate time to conduct a thorough investigation of the officer's actions.

seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

message2: I'm not completely sure that "this is how things improve." I think that there's a difference between identifying a problem and solving it. A lot of times people conflate knowing the problem exists with knowing the solution to the problem, but they're not the same thing. For instance, climate change is real and caused by humans (the problem) but marching in the streets is not actually a solution unless it causes some sort of real change on the part of corporations. The question is, how does justifiable public anger translate to genuine, positive change? It doesn't actually do that on its own, there needs to be specific concrete steps outlined that we can take to turn anger into actions that actually improve the situation.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.
message1: I understand the concern for the alleged victim, and I agree with protecting their physical and mental safety and well-being. However, removing an accused perpetrator based solely on an accusation is a step too far, especially in a country where you are innocent until proven guilty. An accusation is not probable cause, and absent that, I can't see the right to disrupt someone's life to that extent. I would be willing to have an expedited process of getting the matter in front of a judge for a hearing, and if the judge determines there is sufficient evidence to proceed with an investigation, then steps can be taken to separate the accused from the victim, including  restraining orders, protections from abuse, and if the evidence if overwhelming and obvious, removal from campus or the local society. It's too much to say someone should suffer the consequences of the crime merely from an accusation.
message2: I understand completely what you're saying. I am well-aware that the vast majority of accusations are credible, and that false ones are few and far between. I absolutely agree that victim safety is of top priority. I think a good solution would be to adjust the schedules of both parties to ensure they are kept away from each other. It's difficult because this puts burden on the victim, but I don't think removing the alleged perpetrator before an investigation has even begun is the solution. It's a tricky situation.

If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.
message1: In a fair justice system, there is a presumption of innocence. You cannot assume the accused is guilty and punish them before an investiogation has even begun. It is unreasonable, and saying "most accusations are true" is going against the foundation of the justice system, which is that there is a presumption of innocence. While campus rules are not the official justice system, the principles still matter. Precautions can and should be taken to prevent the accused and accuser from encounters, but it is not fair to prematurely punish onew party based on an assumptiuon of guilt.
message2: I understand the concern for the alleged victim, and I agree with protecting their physical and mental safety and well-being. However, removing an accused perpetrator based solely on an accusation is a step too far, especially in a country where you are innocent until proven guilty. An accusation is not probable cause, and absent that, I can't see the right to disrupt someone's life to that extent. I would be willing to have an expedited process of getting the matter in front of a judge for a hearing, and if the judge determines there is sufficient evidence to proceed with an investigation, then steps can be taken to separate the accused from the victim, including  restraining orders, protections from abuse, and if the evidence is overwhelming and obvious, removal from campus or the local society. I would support any reasonable steps to hinder further commissions of the act or similar acts if this person is responsible, and I also think the alleged victim should have free access to whatever support services they feel are necessary.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.
message1: I completely disagree with your conclusions, though not necessarily all of your premises. Unless and until the allegation is proven, we should not be taking away the rights of a potentially innocent accused person.
message2: I see the side from the victim and 100% agree that they should not have to face the risk of seeing their alleged perpetrator. My only stipulation is that this might put the alleged at risk of falling behind in school until there is enough evidence of the crime. Like it or not, someone is innocent until proven guilty in the American court system. Perhaps this balance of not being on campus but not being punished academically for something that has not been officially proven can be struck by having the student participate in distance learning or online classes?

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.

message1: In a situation where an officer of the law needs to protect themselves from a criminal or suspect of a crime, the individual at fault is not the officer. Preservation of ALL human life is a noble ideal, and includes the life of that officer, and furthermore the public, who is being directly and indirectly protected by said officer. Additionally, protection against unreasonable search and seizure is protected in the constitution, so even if an officer violates that principle they can and will be taken to task for it.
message2: While I do agree that people of color have been disproportionately affected by excessive use of force by police, I do not believe that the majority of police behave in the way that us portrayed by the media. Police violence is a symptom of the problem, not the cause. That being said, police need better training on description techniques and use of non-lethal takedown methods.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The reason why I think they should immediately be removed from campus to protect the victim's well being is because statistics back up that false sexual assault reports rarely exist. It is much more easy to just believe the victim instead of the alleged abuser. This is important because we want the victim to feel safe while they are trying to recover and continue on with their education. If you don't do this it'll send a message that you're okay with it. That's not what we should do.
message1: I agree that false reports of assault rarely happen, and I understand their point about wanting the victim to feel safe. I think my issue is that immediately removing the alleged perpetrator could lead to problems before more is known about the case, like people speculating about what happened because the alleged perpetrator was removed. I think a better solution might be to try to separate the alleged perpetrator (e.g., by having them attend classes virtually), until a conclusion is reached in the investigation.
message2: I understand completely what you mean when you say that it is important to protect the victim's well being as when situations like this actually occur it can cause serious mental decline if the issue isn't taken seriously. The point I want to combat though, is that unless it can be proven by other eye-witnesses, then maybe this isn't the best course of action. It could have been anything from actual abuse to just a conflict gone wrong where neither party should be required to leave in the long run.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.

message2: I don't think you've proven that "this is how things improve." I think that there's a difference between identifying a problem and solving it. A lot of times people conflate knowing the problem exists with knowing the solution to the problem, but they're not the same thing. For instance, climate change is real and caused by humans (the problem) but marching in the streets is not actually a solution unless it causes some sort of real change on the part of corporations.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.

The college must treat everyone fairly and react strongly only when there is good cause to do so. To immediately act is to assume the accusation is true. The accuser could have a grudge against the accused and just made it up or maybe a past wrong by the accused against wasn't righted and the accuser did it out of spite. We need to be logical, not driven by emotions, gather evidence and listen to all sides, then decide on a course of action.
message1: I agree that a thorough investigation should take place, but I believe that the accused should be removed from campus while it is being conducted. The instances of false sexual assault allegations are few and far between compared to legitimate ones. The accused could complete classes virtually while the investigation is being conducted. This would keep others on campus safe from repeated sexual assaults in the event that the accused is guilty. We have to keep the well-being of the victim in mind.
message2: I believe the response to the request to ban the accused student from campus needs to be taken cautiously. I agree that further investigation is needed before making a decision based on one accusation. In the same context it wouldn't be a bad idea to keep an eye on both until the issue is resolved.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.
message1: In a fair justice system, there is a presumption of innocence. You cannot assume the accused is guilty and punish them before an investiogation has even begun. It is unreasonable, and saying "most accusations are true" is going against the foundation of the justice system, which is that there is a presumption of innocence. While campus rules are not the official justice system, the principles still matter. Precautions can and should be taken to prevent the accused and accuser from encounters, but it is not fair to prematurely punish onew party based on an assumptiuon of guilt.
message2: Our legal system is founded on the belief that you are innocent until proven guilty. An accusation does not mean guilt. The accused student should have the same rights as everyone else until he/she has been convicted of the crime. If the alleged victim is struggling with being on campus at that time, they can take a break, start therapy, etc.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: I believe that the media plays a major role in blowing these issues out of proportion.  It is easy to take isolated incidents and exploitt them to try and demonstrate profiling or misconduct.  I believe the public reaction is a residue of misinformation or ignorance.  Also- it largly depends on your point of view and your personal experience.
message1: While your point of view may be based on your personal experience, I would argue that people's lack of experience in knowing what it is like to be a minority in that position keeps people from understanding the problem.   A Caucasian person can never fully understand what it is like to be African-American and be pulled over by police, one could assume or try and understand, but never fully grasp the experience.   Even an African-American person who has grown up in wealth, and lives in the suburb may not be able to fully grasp that same experience.    Just because the experience seems blown out of proportion to some, does not negate what minorities experience.  If we fail to put ourselves into someone else's shoes it can be easy to dismiss their problems as being an isolated experience, or an experience that's overblown by the media.
message2: I agree that the media shows only certain aspects of something, but that also tends to change based on the news channel being watched. The problem with the confrontations between police and minorities right now is that these confrontations seem to be so much more explosive than if it was between police and white men. You hear about how much higher the black population in prisons/jails is versus the white population, then you see videos where a black man is being treated so violently, and it can be hard not to assume that it is because of their race, not their crime.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: I completely disagree with this statement. First, reporting about the loss of a life is never overblown. Second we know, and have seen through body cameras and cell phone video, that there is a problem with the way law enforcement interacts with people of color. In fact, people of color are more likely to experience excessive use of force than their white counterparts. This is even true in similar instances. This is not to say that all law enforcement is bad. In fact most law enforcement is here to serve and protect. However, it does point to cultural issues within the institution that must be addressed to restore trust between the groups.
message1: I get that there are some circumstances where police have behaved in a ridiculous manner that has caused lives to be lost.  However, this happens very rarely and I think there is too much emphasis on it being against people of color.  I think there are probably similar instances of this happening to other criminals who may not be of color, and the media doesn't cover this because it is not as compelling to the audience.
message2: I think cultural issues should continually be addressed, you're totally right there. We should be taking each of these situations and examining all instances of excessive force to ascertain the root cause and address training as needed. I will note, though, in the statement, it doesn't specifically address deadly situations, it just says encounters between police and minority crime suspects. There are many times where these encounters end without escalation at all, but if we continually plant the idea that any minority encounter with the police is a racial issue or potentially excessive force or misuse of force, then we're muddying the waters unnecessarily.

message1: Representation of women in STEM is important, but I don't believe the solution to increase it is the one you present. message2: I agree that women who are qualified and dedicated to the STEM field should be fairly represented in hiring practices. I think that the true reason that we see fewer female doctors is because proportionately there are fewer women in the field in general. I believe that the solution to this isn't in hiring practices, but in the way that businesses handle maternity leave and subsequent childcare needs. Women bear the brunt of childrearing, and of course must heal, bond with, and feed their newborns, and strict attendance rules and inflexible management can prevent women from pursuing STEM jobs in the first place.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

issuetext: The United States should invest greater economic, military, and human resources in fighting the spread of ISIS and similar organizations around the world.
seedtext: The United States should not focus its efforts on fighting terrorist groups like ISIS. Also, it would be a more efficient use of money and resources to put it toward humanitarian aid because a little can go a long way for people who are living on less than $2 per day. Note that the U.S. has been trying to "solve" terrorism in Afghanistan for over two decades and still has not "fixed" anything.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: As a woman in STEM, my primary consideration is feeling that I have a fair shot at any position that a man has. I don't expect any preferential treatment or gender-based affirmative action policies to compensate for past gender discrimination in STEM, though. There's a perception in some workplaces with these policies that women were only hired to fill a quota, perpetuating the gender divide. I wouldn't want there to be any doubts about my suitability for the position due to my merit, rather than my gender. Of course, people who hire for STEM positions may have unconscious (or conscious) gender biases, but I think that having a diverse hiring panel would be a better policy than implementing gender quotas.
message1: While I agree that a diverse hiring panel would be helpful in increasing the representation of women in STEM, I think giving preference to women over men, given the same set of qualifications, may more effectively close the gender gap in STEM. I know the word "quota" rubs people the wrong way, and I can understand that - it rubs me the wrong way. However, establishing some sort of system or algorithm that prioritizes hiring women over men - again, when their qualifications are the same - would remove unconscious, internalized bias from the decision making process, and potentially better increase women's representation in STEM. This need not be a permanent solution. Exposure to women in the work field over time would naturally help reduce hiring bias, eventually removing the need for "quotas" as hiring naturally become more equitable.
message2: I see your point and I totally agree with you. I think women should be hired based on their own abilities rather than external factors such as their gender, race, ethnicity, and etc. But I think depends on the situation, the quota policy can be helpful. I believe having a quota will help to reinforce the idea of women have fair position in STEM. This is only a starting point. Because as you said, people may have unconscious biases against women in STEM, if they work in HR, they may skip applications of female applicants. Having a quota will enforce these people to look through every application. But I do admit that there's a con with having a quota which is women are not competing with men but women for the quota when looking for job, but I still feel like the quota is a very good starting point for eradicating (hopefully) gender biases, and once it becomes a norm, company can put out other hiring policies.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: The whole point of feminism is so that both women, men, and any other genders are treated as equals. Giving a competitive edge to women for hiring that is not based on job qualifications and skills seems counter productive to the whole point of feminism. Do I think there's a huge lack of women in STEM? Yes. Is there very likely sexism going on during hiring as it stands now? Oh yeah, definitely. I just don't ideologically agree with blanket boosting a woman's chance at hiring for simply being a women. Something like requiring a gender balance on the hiring committee like half male half female so the candidate receives a relatively more fair and balanced interview.
message1: I can see where you're coming from and do agree to an extent. The problems that prevent women from being hired are a bit more systemic and aren't easily solved by this solution. For one, there's a lack of encouragement to showcase that these degrees and eventual jobs are even possibilities for women. This approach is basically necessary to remedy some of this imbalance. I don't think women would be unfairly provided jobs if this policy went into effect. The ultimate result is that highly qualified women would simply not be overlooked when the hiring decisions in STEM fields are being made. At the moment, they are enormously overlooked and I believe there needs to be a shock to the system in order to correct the issue long-term. However, I do think that your idea of a half male half female hiring committee is a good one and could prove beneficial.
message2: I totally agree with a lot of the arguments and support that you've given regarding giving women priority when hiring for STEM jobs. I think you have an interesting idea about balancing out the hiring committee so that it's a more even split between men and women… which would theoretically result in a more even hiring of men and women. But I wonder if that would help with the hiring of females, especially if there is already more men than women that work at the company. I think in addition to adjusting the hiring committee, there should be some sort of goal that hiring committees can work towards, regarding the ratio of men to women within the overall workplace.

issuetext: The United States should invest greater economic, military, and human resources in fighting the spread of ISIS and similar organizations around the world.
seedtext: The United States should not focus its efforts on fighting terrorist groups like ISIS. It would be a much better use of resources to focus on fighting hunger, climate change, lack of education and humanitarian problems such at those in foreign, and especially low-income, countries. In the long run this would have the effect of reducing terrorism because when people have stable lives and do not worry about their day-to-day survival they are less likely to become radicalized. Also, it would be a more efficient use of money and resources to put it toward humanitarian aid because a little can go a long way for people who are living on less than $2 per day. With military and counter-terrorism funding, you just keep spending and spending and the problem doesn't go away. Note that the U.S. has been trying to "solve" terrorism in Afghanistan for over two decades and still has not "fixed" anything.
message1: Sometimes even people who have not experirenced hardship make bad decision or interact with the wrong people. Using money to lessen problems they face does not guarantee that they won't be radicalized. I think it is important to invest money in protecting the United States from terrorists organizations.
message2: You are very correct that investing in a country's infrastructure, independent food supplies, education, etc. would greatly reduce the need for military intervention in the long run. However, ISIS has shown that they willing use their people's poverty and lack of education, even using their young men as 'cannon fodder." In the short term, there is no alternative to military intervention, especially if many people would be threatened or killed. The best solution would be to do both, military intervention preceded and/or followed by investments in people's lives.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: Women have been historically underrepresented in the fields of math, science and engineering. issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The reason why I think they should immediately be removed from campus to protect the victim's well being is because statistics back up that false sexual assault reports rarely exist. message1: The problem with this is that if there is no proof other than word of mouth then anyone has the potential to be damaged significantly just by words. If they end up being guilty then they would deserve all of this though. It doesn’t send a message that it’s ok but rather respects the due process of law.
message2: I agree with you that there are very few false sexual assault accusations. However, the investigative process needs to play out before people are removed from campus. I don't believe anyone should be removed from campus until an investigation is completed. An accusation shouldn't be enough to get someone removed from campus. "Innocent until proven guilty." Do you know how many accusations are unfounded each year ? The discrepancy is astounding.  I have included a link for your review.  " In an analysis of sexual-assault cases at a large university for a 10-year period, a study found that 44.9% of cases “did not proceed” – meaning the incident did not meet the legal standard of assault, there was insufficient evidence, or the accuser was uncooperative.  David Lisak, Lori Gardinier, Sarah C. Nicksa, and Ashley M. Cote, “False Allegations of Sexual Assault: An Analysis of Ten Years of Reported Cases,” Violence Against Women 16(12) 1318-1334 (2010).http://notavictim.tyla.org/accused/guide-college-students/   As you can see with this information there are numerous individuals who have been accused, lost their reputation, not given a fair "judging" of their peers, lost scholarships and the right to continue with their education. While it is important to make the staff and student body aware of a potential incident we also have a duty to protect the rights and privacy of both parties for fear of lawsuits, aggression and other acts of violence that can be preventable.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.

message1: No, there isn’t an “epic” number of minorities getting killed by the police. Have you dissected the statistics properly and read which minorities were affected the most? As a Korean woman living in the US, I consider myself a visible minority. I don’t see fellow Korean Americans getting killed by the police on an epic scale. Clearly it’s not happening all across the board with all the minority groups. That is a huge generalization and you know it. So I advise you to carefully look at the statistics and really narrow down which racial groups are affected the most and study why those groups are experiencing this. issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.

message1: While I do agree it can be frustrating to see others viewed as superior simply due to their gender and not necessarily their capability, I do not believe preferential hiring based on gender would solve this. On the other hand, advanced degree attainment across all fields, including STEM, has been increasing among women and decreasing among men. I believe due to this, in time, we will see a natural progression towards a larger representation of women in these roles which will hopefully alleviate your concerns of women being seen as lesser.
message2: I absolutely agree that women need to be "empowered" in STEM fields. But those efforts to encourage female participation in those fields of study will eventually affect how they are treated in the workplace and they will earn the respect of their colleagues.     Furthermore, the question didn't ask if women are discriminated against in the workplace, nor did it ask if women in STEM fields should be "empowered." It asked if they should receive preference in hiring. And to this I would emphatically say no, because that very preference would undercut their perceived value. If a woman's co-workers all assume she only got her job because she was given a preference over others who were more qualified, she's not going to earn any true respect.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.
message1: Our legal system is founded on the belief that you are innocent until proven guilty. An accusation does not mean guilt. The accused student should have the same rights as everyone else until he/she has been convicted of the crime. If the alleged victim is struggling with being on campus at that time, they can take a break, start therapy, etc.
message2: I under stand that we want to support sexual assault victims. But we also need to keep the innocent until proven guilty mentality. Removing the accused imposes an unsaid guilty verdict and damages someones reputation before any due process. If one person is to be removed, both parties should be removed. This would protect BOTH parties until discovery is complete. This still supports and protects the victims of sexual assault and helps negate what's become guilty until proven innocent that we have turned this towards. I can point you at multiple stories where the accuser was actually just a liar and did irreparable harm to an innocent person.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: While I am supportive of an increase in representation of women in math, sciences, and engineering, I do not believe the best method of achieving this is to give blanket priority to female graduates over male graduates. There is no doubt that women have historically been under-represented in fields such as math and engineering, however by giving women graduates a priority over men simply because of the fact they are women could lead to less-talented candidates entering the field. I believe a better method would be to simply look at the resume/qualifications of the candidate and choose based off of who is more qualified, therefore leading to a "blind" and more objective hiring process.
message1: A fair hiring process takes into consideration the fact that we do not live in a meritocracy. Given that the judging of candidates will most likely be performed by those who have privilege and access to resources that most women do not, judging the candidates on the exact same basis as one another without taking these disparities into consideration would lead to an unbalanced hiring process. In other words, there is no such thing as a truly "blind" hiring process; the most we can aim for is a fair one - not to mention considering the enhancements to the field the additional viewpoints a women's lived experience can bring.
message2: For the most part, I agree with this sentiment, I don't think less qualified women should be hired. I do think that unless employers are going to institute a completely blind hiring process, it is valuable to recognize any biases against women that might exist. I also think women have a tendency to downplay their skills on a resume for fear of appearing arrogant and that this should be taken into consideration.

Infractions of rules, overstepping authority and so forth. Typically those who say it is overblown are not minorities or if they are they are minorities who themselves are police. There seems to be an understanding that it is not an issue because we have not reach an epic number. Isn't one innocent person killed too much?
message1: No, there isn’t an “epic” number of minorities getting killed by the police. Have you dissected the statistics properly and read which minorities were affected the most? As a Korean woman living in the US, I consider myself a visible minority. I don’t see fellow Korean Americans getting killed by the police on an epic scale. Clearly it’s not happening all across the board with all the minority groups. That is a huge generalization and you know it. So I advise you to carefully look at the statistics and really narrow down which racial groups are affected the most and study why those groups are experiencing this. I have seen many videos where male criminals resist arrest even though the police had asked them to cooperate with the arrest and had proper grounds to ask them to do so. Not cooperating with the police puts the police at danger and makes their job difficult. We need to consider the lives of the police as well.
message2: I agree there are some police officers with questionable history, but at the same time there are a lot of criminals out there killing other innocent people and committing different types of crime. We cannot blame the police officers only. Many of these criminals carry guns as well.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: I work in a healthcare field currently, working with mostly women. Men doing my same role and duties are sometimes mistaken to be physicians merely because they are men. In order to change this viewpoint, we need to see women in these roles as they are just as qualified and dedicated to this type of work. It is not just about stigma of men versus women. It is about empowering women in STEM fields. They are not recognized and should be built up in these fields.
message1: While I agree that women who are qualified and dedicated to the field should be represented in hiring practices, I do not think that they should be disproportionately represented compared to the actual number of women in the field vs. men. I think that the true reason that we see fewer female doctors is because proportionately there are fewer women in the field in general. I believe that the solution to this isn't in hiring practices, but in the way that businesses handle maternity leave and subsequent childcare needs. Women bear the brunt of childrearing, and of course must heal, bond with, and feed their newborns, and strict attendance rules and inflexible management can prevent women from pursuing STEM jobs in the first place.
message2: I agree with you, society has it ingrained in our minds what roles, men and women are seen in. People need to see women are just as capable as men,  more awareness , that visibly shows that would help in empowering women. With more women entering into fields traditionally held by men, we need to find a way to spotlight the women who are in the field. One way to do this is in the hospitals, and clinics have posters of the staff and their roles , placed throughout the buildings, people will see it and realize that its not just men in the leading roles.

issuetext: The United States should invest greater economic, military, and human resources in fighting the spread of ISIS and similar organizations around the world.
seedtext: I do not believe that the United States should be spending more military, economic and human resources in the fight against ISIS.  I believe that we need to change our mentality on the situation and see that what we are doing militarily against ISIS is not working.  We have been fighting these so called terrorists organizations for quite sometime and the problem is still ongoing.  Organizations like ISIS believe that the United States are the terrorists and are fighting their battle against terrorism themselves.  I believe that the sole answer to fighting these organizations is education and getting people out of poverty to give them something to live for.  The fight against ISIS is a losing battle and for everyone that we kill seems to get more of them motivated to fight us in return.
message1: Terrorism is an ongoing battle. We must stay active and vigilant around the world to keep it at bay. Other countries may see us as the terrorists, but they still threaten our livelihood.
message2: I believe the United States should continue to spend military, economic, and human resources in the fight against ISIS, in addition to other strategies to counter these organizations. These organizations are indeed terrorist in ideology and actions regardless of how they view themselves and others. Military action has proven effective in countering ISIS and al Qaeda where they had been geographically entrenched. Education and getting people out of poverty are also effective strategies and should be utilized, however they are far from the sole answer. Many people who join these organizations are highly educated and come from well off families. Osama bin Laden was well known to have come from a wealthy and influential family. Proving that these organizations are not divinely invincible in battle is part of the strategy for exposing the weakness of their fundamentalist religious ideology. It is also important to expose the brutal atrocities committed by these organizations, not just against Western powers, but against civilians in areas controlled by them, including non-Muslims and Muslims they consider heretics, as well as many of their own recruits. Another important strategy is offering deprogramming therapy for prisoners captured from these organizations and those who voluntarily defect.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: The whole point of feminism is so that both women, men, and any other genders are treated as equals. Giving a competitive edge to women for hiring that is not based on job qualifications and skills seems counter productive to the whole point of feminism. Do I think there's a huge lack of women in STEM? Yes. Is there very likely sexism going on during hiring as it stands now? Oh yeah, definitely. I just don't ideologically agree with blanket boosting a woman's chance at hiring for simply being a women. Something like requiring a gender balance on the hiring committee like half male half female so the candidate receives a relatively more fair and balanced interview.
message1: The problem currently is that while more women are entering STEM fields, they often hit a glass ceiling in advancement of their careers. In fact, even female dominated STEM fields end up having hardly any female representation at the upper levels. The extra higher incentives are not an advantage, but a leveling of the playing field in historically male dominated fields.
message2: I can see where you're coming from and do agree to an extent. The problems that prevent women from being hired are a bit more systemic and aren't easily solved by this solution. For one, there's a lack of encouragement to showcase that these degrees and eventual jobs are even possibilities for women. This approach is basically necessary to remedy some of this imbalance. I don't think women would be unfairly provided jobs if this policy went into effect. The ultimate result is that highly qualified women would simply not be overlooked when the hiring decisions in STEM fields are being made. At the moment, they are enormously overlooked and I believe there needs to be a shock to the system in order to correct the issue long-term. However, I do think that your idea of a half-male half-female hiring committee is a good one and could prove beneficial.

issuetext: The United States should invest greater economic, military, and human resources in fighting the spread of ISIS and similar organizations around the world.
seedtext: While ISIS is simply a symptom of a larger problem plaguing countries in the middle east, their existence provides no value to the region or the world in any way. Their archaic interpretation of Islam and brutal murders, tortures, and rapes of their own country men and women proves they are simply mindless barbarians who need to be stopped. The United States should not lose sight of the hard fought gains in countries like Iraq and continue to support governments that are fighting ISIS on the ground whether that be through logistical, financial or military means. Groups like ISIS need to be quickly and swiftly destroyed to prevent their actions and if done swiftly enough discourage other similar groups from forming in the future.
message1: The problem with ISIS is fundamentalist ideology. Fundamentalist ideologies cannot be removed by waging war. Removing ISIS by force will create a power vacuum, which may result in an even more dangerous element taking control in the Middle East.
message2: The US should definitely act to prevent the influence of groups like ISIS, but I disagree with the idea that the US should work to "quickly and swiftly destroy" these groups in general.  Confronting these groups in military fashion can involve huge costs in dollars and military lives, and risks larger wars and conflicts and alienating our allies.  We should combat these groups on many fronts, including education, aid, diplomacy and military action as a last resort.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: Historically, women have not had access to higher education, and for those women that do, sexism has oftentimes prohibited them from getting well-paid positions. Math, sciences, and engineering has historically been a male-dominated field. It has proved to be difficult for women to be in these environments, due to less female-friendly work environments and more stories of sexual assault. In addition, hiring decisions make it less likely that male-dominated spaces would hire a woman with similar credentials to a man. In order to increase representation and make these workplaces more equitable, women with relevant degrees should be given priority over men.
message1: I can completely understand your point of view however I respectfully disagree. Women have fought very hard for equality and giving us a leg up isn't equal treatment. Perhaps people in the STEM industry should be hired completely on their qualifications rather than their gender. If we could take gender completely off of the resume that would be the most fair and equal way to hire someone.
message2: While I appreciate the inequality of many workplaces, the solution to sexism is not more sexism. Men and women are equally gifted and capable at nearly every task and career path. It is therefore important to see to it that we hire only on merit and not on immutable characteristics such as gender or race. I oppose biased hiring and I oppose affirmative action whether it be for past race or gender discrimination. I support meritorious female empowerment, not the government passing laws to give women their own power.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Having someone immediately removed from a campus just because someone made an accusation against them is a little ridiculous. This fear would come from knowing that if they say the wrong thing or act the wrong way they could be taken off campus without proof. Now if there is immediate proof then I completely agree that they should be kicked out, however without a good amount of evidence to prove something happened then I think kicking the students off campus should wait.
message1: I agree it is important to have evidence to believe an assault has taken place. It is also important for all students to feel safe on campus. A sexual predator is likely to reoffend, or take revenge on an accuser. This means the accused poses a threat to the campus community.
message2: Well, to be fair, separation of the accused away from the sexual assault accuser can prove to be the best course of action until the issue is resolved. This will maintain the peace until the campus gets to the bottom of the investigation. Maybe removing the accused from the campus is a tad bit draconian. I would go as far as to say to at least removed the accused to a separate part of the campus that's strictly for disciplinary actions until the investigation is over with. This way, the accused won't have to automatically be kicked off of campus, while the accuser can still safely maintain their distance away from the accused.

message1: I agree with you now, however I do want to bring up an important note. I believe that you are right in saying that there are rarely false sexual assault reports, due to the severity in consequences if they are false. False sexual assault reports can tear innocent individuals' lives apart in the extremely rare chance that it is false.
message2: While I agree with the logic of your statement, I also believe that everyone is innocent until proven guilty. " In an analysis of sexual-assault cases at a large university for a 10-year period, a study found that 44.9% of cases “did not proceed” – meaning the incident did not meet the legal standard of assault, there was insufficient evidence, or the accuser was uncooperative.  David Lisak, Lori Gardinier, Sarah C. Nicksa, and Ashley M. issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.

message1: This argument assumes that we live in a fair meritocracy. We don't live in such a world. Any suggestion that we do is pushed by those who have benefited from such an illusion. message2: I don't agree that such a decision would equal discrimination against men. Multiple studies have shown that diversity in social settings produces the best and most varied results. When only a specific group of people is at the table to give ideas, creativity is stymied, and you run the risk of creating an echo chamber. Every workplace can be improved by the benefits of alternate viewpoints and differing life experiences.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: Yes it has been overblown.  The media has portrayed these incidents to be much more common than they actually are, which has fueled the public reaction to be greater than necessary.  The public reaction has largely overlooked the fact that the majority of these incidents have been started with a suspect resisting a lawful arrest.  It has focused almost exclusively on the officer's actions and ignored the fact that nothing detrimental would have occurred had the suspect complied with the officer's orders.  There has also been rioting and destruction by some in the public that has not accomplished anything positive.  Another overreaction is in the public's call for an immediate termination or filing of criminal charges against an officer when there has not been adequate time to conduct a thorough investigation of the officer's actions.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: As a woman in STEM, my primary consideration is feeling that I have a fair shot at any position that a man has. I don't expect any preferential treatment or gender-based affirmative action policies to compensate for past gender discrimination in STEM, though. There's a perception in some workplaces with these policies that women were only hired to fill a quota, perpetuating the gender divide. I wouldn't want there to be any doubts about my suitability for the position due to my merit, rather than my gender. Of course, people who hire for STEM positions may have unconscious (or conscious) gender biases, but I think that having a diverse hiring panel would be a better policy than implementing gender quotas.
message1: Wile I agree that a diverse hiring panel would be helpful in increasing the representation of women in STEM, I think giving preference to women over men, given the same set of qualifications, would more effectively close the gender gap in STEM. I know the word "quota" rubs people the wrong way, and I can understand that - it rubs me the wrong way. However, establishing some sort of system or algorithm that prioritizes hiring women over men - again, when their qualifications are the same, would remove unconscious, internalized bias from the decision making process, and better increase women's representation in STEM. This need not be a permanent solution. Exposure to women in the work field over time would naturally help reduce hiring bias.
message2: I can see your point and I can fully agree with your statment

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.

This still supports and protects the victims of sexual assault and helps negate what's become guilty until proven innocent that we have turned this towards. I can point you at multiple stories where the accuser was actually just a liar and did irreparable harm to an innocent person.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: As a woman in STEM, my primary consideration is feeling that I have a fair shot at any position that a man has. I don't expect any preferential treatment or gender-based affirmative action policies to compensate for past gender discrimination in STEM, though. There's a perception in some workplaces with these policies that women were only hired to fill a quota, perpetuating the gender divide. I wouldn't want there to be any doubts about my suitability for the position due to my merit, rather than my gender. Of course, people who hire for STEM positions may have unconscious (or conscious) gender biases, but I think that having a diverse hiring panel would be a better policy than implementing gender quotas.
message1: I think this is a very reasonable and nuanced response to the prompt. I agree, instead of affirmative action policies it would be much more effective to have more diverse hiring panels to help remove gender biases. As you stated, affirmative action policies could lead to doubts about if you got a position based on merit or gender alone. It's impossible to 'fix' or compensate for past gender discrimination in STEM, we can only try to improve in the fairest way possible to everyone.
message2: I think you'd have trouble getting that diverse hiring panel in some companies without making an effort to hire more women. And then couldn't the argument be made that the women on the hiring panel weren't qualified to be on it (different department, don't have the subject matter expertise, etc.) and were only chosen to fill a quota? I think they'd also feel internal pressure to judge women candidates very carefully to avoid the appearance that they're favoring women. I see what you're saying about following a normal process rather than having a specific affirmative action policy, but I think that the same dynamics that perpetuate the gender gap in STEM would apply to the hiring panel so I can't see that being a successful solution.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: As a woman in STEM, my primary consideration is feeling that I have a fair shot at any position that a man has. I don't expect any preferential treatment or gender-based affirmative action policies to compensate for past gender discrimination in STEM, though. There's a perception in some workplaces with these policies that women were only hired to fill a quota, perpetuating the gender divide. I wouldn't want there to be any doubts about my suitability for the position due to my merit, rather than my gender. Of course, people who hire for STEM positions may have unconscious (or conscious) gender biases, but I think that having a diverse hiring panel would be a better policy than implementing gender quotas.
message1: Women are as capable as men in STEM. I fully understand your concerns and I hope this unconscious gender biases may slowly disappear. I know many super qualified women work in STEM and their performance is actually better than men's. Therefore, I have no doubt that women are as capable as men in STEM.
message2: I think the term "affirmative action" often comes with a lot of baggage and it is misunderstood, so I agree with you that programs that further perpetuate a gender divide are not good. However, I think the term or these policies can be applied more broadly. For example, what you suggested of having a diverse hiring panel could be considered a form of affirmative action. I agree that if any of these policies are to be implemented, they should be done carefully so as to not make individuals feel that they are being hired to feel a quote, as opposed to being hired for their qualifications. However, I acknowledge that, as a man, I am one step removed from this and that the voices of women should be just as equally heard. I think the main goal of any affirmative action program is to ensure that those who are qualified (whether they be women or men) are all considered and given a fair chance.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: I disagree with this statement for a few reasons. The public reaction has had the benefit of forcing the issues of police misconduct which generations of Americans have experienced with no justice or protection to the forefront of public policy in the country.  Without public pressure and a serious acknowedgement of unqeual protection under the law , these crimes against minority communities would continue to be swept under the rug. Also, if the situations were not broadcast in everyone's living rooms, the general majority public who many times have no experience with these injustices, nor knowlege of how  injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere will feel like they dont have a vested interest in developing solutions to the core issues that cause crime (i.e. lack of economic development, race, community distrust etc). If the instances of police brutality and incarceration were being perpetuated on the majority class there would be no end to the public confrontation.
message1: Extreme inequality leads to the inability of some segments of society to achieve basic goods and services. Imagine a neighborhood with mostly working-class people. Most of the shops and restaurants cater to the local population, offering affordable goods and food. Then, let's say that there is a large influx of much wealthier people. Shops and restaurants can (and will) increase their prices, and rent prices go up
message2: You are claiming that these "injustices" are not being perpetuated on the majority class. When in fact they are. There is also another key difference here, the "majority class" also commits less crime and therefore has less interaction with police even though they are a majority of the population. When one "class" has the most interaction with police, it is a no brainer that they will have the most issue with the treatment. Police are not perfect and there are bad apples in all areas of life. There have been definite issues that have come up that were not justified, and those need addressed, but we also need to be truthful to what actually happened in many of these publicized "injustices".

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: Yes it has been overblown.  The media has portrayed these incidents to be much more common than they actually are, which has fueled the public reaction to be greater than necessary.  The public reaction has largely overlooked the fact that the majority of these incidents have been started with a suspect resisting a lawful arrest.  It has focused almost exclusively on the officer's actions and ignored the fact that nothing detrimental would have occurred had the suspect complied with the officer's orders.  There has also been rioting and destruction by some in the public that has not accomplished anything positive.  Another overreaction is in the public's call for an immediate termination or filing of criminal charges against an officer when there has not been adequate time to conduct a thorough investigation of the officer's actions.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.
message1: Agreed. We should not consider someone guilty without evidence. However, the deck is stacked against survivors of sexual assault. They are often not believed. Our society still makes assumptions about the way a person is dressed. Given this history and the unconscious assumptions we all make about people, it's really important that we recognize the need to believe those who have suffered a sexual assault. Rather than rationalize it away, wouldn't it be better if we took people at their word and investigated appropriately?
message2: I agree that victims should be believed and that they are deserving of protection, but I disagree with the accused not facing any consequences. While I am hesitantly in support of removing the student, I do think restraining orders or something protective would be a good way for the accused student to remain, but also a good way for the victim to feel comfortable.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
