issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.

She almost ruined someone else's life and if he were "removed" from campus it would have had a greater negative impact on his life.
message2: I understand completely what you're saying. I am well-aware that the vast majority of accusations are credible, and that false ones are few and far between. issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.
message1: I disagree with your reasoning.  I do feel that you need to trust and believe the victim but you must also give trust and belief to the accused. She almost ruined someone else's life and if he were "removed" from campus it would have had a greater negative impact on his life.
message2: I do not believe that the alleged perpetrator should be removed immediately. You cannot punish someone for something that has not been proven. issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

However, it would be unfair to ban the accused from campus if they haven't been proved guilty, because there is still the possibility that they are innocent.

I believe a better method would be to simply look at the resume/qualifications of the candidate and choose based off of who is more qualified, therefore leading to a "blind" and more objective hiring process.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: As a woman in STEM, my primary consideration is feeling that I have a fair shot at any position that a man has. I wouldn't want there to be any doubts about my suitability for the position due to my merit, rather than my gender. Of course, people who hire for STEM positions may have unconscious (or conscious) gender biases, but I think that having a diverse hiring panel would be a better policy than implementing gender quotas.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.
message1: In the United States, a person is innocent of a crime UNTIL PROVEN guilty.  Removing the "alleged" perpertrator of campus sexual assault--with no proof--is placing punishment before any criminal conviction.  What is the "alleged" victim is lying--which is a frequent occurrence?    The statement that victims don't accuse sexual assault unless it's true is interesting, and also HOGWASH.  Do you recall the crazy woman going after President Biden for "assault" at the train station?
message2: In a fair justice system, there is a presumption of innocence. You cannot assume the accused is guilty and punish them before an investiogation has even begun. It is unreasonable, and saying "most accusations are true" is going against the foundation of the justice system, which is that there is a presumption of innocence. While campus rules are not the official justice system, the principles still matter. Precautions can and should be taken to prevent the accused and accuser from encounters, but it is not fair to prematurely punish onew party based on an assumptiuon of guilt.

seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.
message1: I agree that the rights of the accused should be protected as well as the accuser.  I also agree that unless a person has a particular background or there is some relevancy to the current case, there should be no extra measure taken for the accused until the proceedings are addressed in court.  However, there are a number of situations which require an extra step for the protection of the accused, as they tend to be women who may not feel as secure as men might with similar circumstances.
message2: I completely agree with the fact you have stated above. Someone can not be removed from campus just because they are accused of something. Like you said, innocent until proven guilty in America.

But, we do not, as a society, say that all nurses are bad and out to kill patients. Also, lets look at all of the area where police forces have been parried down and down. All of those areas have massively increased crime and violent crime over the past 3 years. We were told that getting rid of so many police would lessen crime, and yet we see the complete opposite.
message2: I completely agree. It's not overblown as people thing. Even if it IS overblown, its still happening and it is still unacceptable- and nobody has done anything to mitigate it. issuetext: The United States should invest greater economic, military, and human resources in fighting the spread of ISIS and similar organizations around the world.
seedtext: The reason that I disagree with this topic is that we need to be more focused on our own citizens first. Of course, the safety of threats is important as well, but it should not be our sole focus. message1: Securing America from outside threats is vitally important. There are many issues that are integral as well. But if we don't strengthen our military, it all becomes moot. We need America to be strong and secure, first and foremost.
message2: The United States is the single most powerful and influential nation on the face of the earth. We are prosperous and wealthy and have the means to pursue more than one strategy or focus on a single issue at a time. I can't think of any nation in the world who is not at least somewhat engaged in and dependent on the global economy as it has evolved to date. Every nation has domestic issues and every nation has international interests and economic dependencies. Both have to be addressed at all times. We are not a standalone nation with no outside economic interests. We have alliances with many nations in Europe and Asia who increasingly face threats from Russia, China, North Korea and terrorist groups who recognize no authority whatsoever. As the global economy goes, so goes the United States. International trade is domestic trade. It is true that funding issues require agreement between domestic and international problems that need to be solved but those debates have always been there since the country was founded. If our government is only capable of handling one problem at a time then we have already failed. We must defend our both economic and national security interests domestically and overseas if necessary. If we don't engage our enemies over there then we'll end up engaging our enemies here at home.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: As a woman in STEM, my primary consideration is feeling that I have a fair shot at any position that a man has. I don't expect any preferential treatment or gender-based affirmative action policies to compensate for past gender discrimination in STEM, though. There's a perception in some workplaces with these policies that women were only hired to fill a quota, perpetuating the gender divide. I wouldn't want there to be any doubts about my suitability for the position due to my merit, rather than my gender. Of course, people who hire for STEM positions may have unconscious (or conscious) gender biases, but I think that having a diverse hiring panel would be a better policy than implementing gender quotas.
message1: I think you'd have trouble getting that diverse hiring panel in some companies without making an effort to hire more women. And then couldn't the argument be made that the women on the hiring panel weren't qualified to be on it (different department, don't have the subject matter expertise, etc.) and were only chosen to fill a quota? I think they'd also feel internal pressure to judge women candidates very carefully to avoid the appearance that they're favoring women. I just don't see that as a solution.
message2: You raise a good point about the need for a diverse hiring panel. Even though this would help in getting more women hired into stem, inherent bias may stlll be present both in male and female panel members that skews favor towards hiring men. For this reason, I feel a diverse hiring panel AND quotas towards hiring women into STEM are important.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: I believe women are underrepresented in the workplace in general, so they deserve special treatment. Of course, choosing a woman over a man should only happen if they have the same qualifications, or if the woman is more qualified. Women historically have not had the same rights in the workplace as men, and now is a good time to make up for that. By hiring more women, social stigmas and stereotypes might disappear as well. It is important to show society that women can do more than just stay at home and cook.
message1: Woman are underrepresented in the workplace, but that is because some woman choose not to work. Instead, some woman choose to stay at home and be a homemaker and raise kids. Woman should not receive special treatment. I believe that someone should be hired for a job based on their abilities to perform the job, not based on their sex, color, or any other superficial feature. If the woman is better for the job, hire her. If the man is better for the job, hire him. It's that simple. No special treatment is needed.
message2: It’s a very interesting thought to perpetuate that women are underrepresented in STEM.  For now, sure there are technically fewer women in advanced roles or leadership roles,  but it’s actively changing without being so aggressive.  As of the last 5 years, women in general are increasingly over-represented in graduate school for these fields as well as medicine.  When I was in medical school 65% of my class was female.  It turns out that women are natural leaders, too, and given equal opportunity the better candidate still wins.  There are a lot of issues regarding a level playing field, but chalking it all up to gender bias in 2022 is not realistic.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: Hiring decisions could be made relatively blindly in order to give everyone a more equal chance.  The interviewers or individuals making a hiring decision should, when initially reading through applicants' resumes, read the relevant information with gender-identifying language (ie, names) removed if need be.  We as women are not in need of affirmative-action type policies.  I strongly believe our achievements, education, and experiences are robust enough to stand on their own.  Why would I want to get a job where afterwards co-workers whisper that I was a mandatory hire, or that they "had" to hire a woman?  I would feel uncomfortable being there.

This may be the best way to ensure an equal number of qualified women are hired rather than hiring by chance.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The reason why I think they should immediately be removed from campus to protect the victim's well being is because statistics back up that false sexual assault reports rarely exist. It is much more easy to just believe the victim instead of the alleged abuser. This is important because we want the victim to feel safe while they are trying to recover and continue on with their education. If you don't do this it'll send a message that you're okay with it. That's not what we should do.
message1: While I understand the case for immediately removing the accused from campus, I also genuinely believe that due process needs to be followed to ensure proper protocol and investigation are followed. I am in no way saying that cases are overblown, and I believe that there are safety measures that can be put in place (i.e. removing this person from the victim's vicinity by not being allowed in dining halls, dorms, removing from any shared classes, etc) as well as supporting the accused with emotional, criminal justice, and support. However, an instant removal just reinforces the overblown criminal justice system, which often does not follow proper protocol, and does not assume the accused is innocent until proven otherwise.     This is a personal issue for me: I was sexually assaulted on my college campus, and the college was reluctant to offer help. Thankfully, I went to the local police department, which was able to guide me through the proper channels. I did not want the individual removed from campus, and was able to restore our relationship via a restorative justice process facilitated by an outside group. This was tremendous for my healing, and would never have been possible if this individual was instantly removed from campus.
message2: I understand completely what you mean when you say that it is important to protect the victim's well being as when situations like this actually occur it can cause serious mental decline if the issue isn't taken seriously. The point I want to convey though, is that unless it can be proven by other eye-witnesses, then maybe this isn't the best course of action. It could have been anything from actual abuse to just a conflict gone wrong where neither party should be required to leave in the long run. It should be noted that it's important to hear out both sides fully before making judgements.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: While I am supportive of an increase in representation of women in math, sciences, and engineering, I do not believe the best method of achieving this is to give blanket priority to female graduates over male graduates. There is no doubt that women have historically been under-represented in fields such as math and engineering, however by giving women graduates a priority over men simply because of the fact they are women could lead to less-talented candidates entering the field. I believe a better method would be to simply look at the resume/qualifications of the candidate and choose based off of who is more qualified, therefore leading to a "blind" and more objective hiring process.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.
message1: I understand the concern for the alleged victim, and I agree with protecting their physical and mental safety and well-being. However, removing an accused perpetrator based solely on an accusation is a step too far, especially in a country where you are innocent until proven guilty. An accusation is not probable cause, and absent that, I can't see the right to disrupt someone's life to that extent. I would be willing to have an expedited process of getting the matter in front of a judge for a hearing, and if the judge determines there is sufficient evidence to proceed with an investigation, then steps can be taken to separate the accused from the victim, including  restraining orders, protections from abuse, and if the evidence if overwhelming and obvious, removal from campus or the local society. It's too much to say someone should suffer the consequences of the crime merely from an accusation.
message2: I don't think any student should be removed from a campus simply due to do an accusation. There needs to be some kind of evidence. Otherwise you are in a situation where there is no due process at all.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: The public reaction has not been overblown, if anything it is severely muted.  Recent confrontations are simply making visible issues that have existed for a very long time. There are real issues between police and the communities they serve that are only being addressed because of the attention being paid through Black Lives Matter and other protests. This is how things improve, even if it is hard and difficult to discuss.

message2: I disagree. I think the BLM movement is a farce and is not interested in justice. They are only interested in their money and publicity. issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: While I am supportive of an increase in representation of women in math, sciences, and engineering, I do not believe the best method of achieving this is to give blanket priority to female graduates over male graduates. There is no doubt that women have historically been under-represented in fields such as math and engineering, however by giving women graduates a priority over men simply because of the fact they are women could lead to less-talented candidates entering the field. I believe a better method would be to simply look at the resume/qualifications of the candidate and choose based off of who is more qualified, therefore leading to a "blind" and more objective hiring process.
message1: I agree with you that we can't hire candidates blindly of the representation of as a "whole" (in general) Because there are some women you absolutely kill men in their resume, degrees they have and qualifications in the field of math, science, and engineering.    I would hire a women in a heartbeat if her resume and qualifications exceled over a candidate male who's resume and qualifications who's just as good and excellent for the job, but if she has that one extra inch of experience (aka qualification's) then I'm going to hire her instead of the male.    You have to look at both sides logically instead of emotionally or what the stereotypical of "male's are better than women in this so called field" because civilization through out history told us this and has in-grained it onto are brains.
message2: I agree that blind hiring processes should be the standard. However, I believe that it is important to consider the whole person and the culture of the organization when making hiring decisions as well. If there are equally talented men and women, it is important to try to achieve diversity and parity.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Not only should the person who has been accused of sexual assault be immediately removed from campus, but should be removed from society. No one can justify allowing someone to continue to terrorize others. Unfortunately, we have to wait for the wheels of justice to turn to put away predators. The horrors that victims face just knowing that the predator may still be out there can cause all sorts of stress and post traumatic stress. The sooner that we can get someone who is convicted and proven to be dangerous off of the street, the better for all of us in society.
message1: While I do agree dangerous people need to be removed from campus if there is proof, if someone is simply accused that is not enough to justify removal from campus or society. There are many reasons someone could falsely accuse another person. It would make the most sense for someone to provide evidence first and then be removed. Sexual assault is a despicable act and needs to be heavily punished however an accusation is not enough reason to remove someone from campus.
message2: Ridiculous that someone would advocate for the termination of a life without finding out first whether or not they were even guilty in the first place. Due process is the law of the land and even if you don't like the person based a crime they may have committed they are still well within their rights to a fair trial and or investigation on the matter. Jumping to conclusions can only harm people in the long run.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: I do not feel that any candidate should be given priority in hiring decisions.  If they were given priority, this is essentially discriminating against men. If a woman was given priority, this could lead to a less qualified candidate getting hired.  It could also lead to resentment in the workplace.
message1: While it is true that we should support merit and not discriminate, this has happened over time with women in these positions. What you are describing is equality, meaning that people begin at the same place. But we know that there are socialization factors in schools that deter women from pursuing these careers, as well as factors in the workplace. With equity, we are trying to correct this imbalance.
message2: I admire your response and I agree with you that in theory I feel this is the practice that all employers should implement.  I do however think that since there has been such a discrepancy with women in math and science that there may need to be a bump in the hiring of women to help equalize and reduce the gap.  Not by any means giving a job to a less qualified candidate, but perhaps if all things are even, they would give that opportunity to the woman over the man.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: Historically, women have not had access to higher education, and for those women that do, sexism has oftentimes prohibited them from getting well-paid positions. In addition, hiring decisions make it less likely that male-dominated spaces would hire a woman with similar credentials to a man. In order to increase representation and make these workplaces more equitable, women with relevant degrees should be given priority over men.
message1: I agree that women historically have been denied access to higher education and for the women that succeeded in doing so have often been the victims of sexism in high paid positions.  However, I believe that the misdeeds of the past should not be corrected by misdeeds of the present. Along with who's credentials, experience and temperament is best suited for the particular workplace environment to be the hiring template.
message2: Gender should not be a factor for positions in the workplace but instead if the person is qualified or not.  Women who are qualified will be considered as well as men, it should be equal consideration.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: Yes it has been overblown.  The media has portrayed these incidents to be much more common than they actually are, which has fueled the public reaction to be greater than necessary.  The public reaction has largely overlooked the fact that the majority of these incidents have been started with a suspect resisting a lawful arrest.  It has focused almost exclusively on the officer's actions and ignored the fact that nothing detrimental would have occurred had the suspect complied with the officer's orders.  There has also been rioting and destruction by some in the public that has not accomplished anything positive.  Another overreaction is in the public's call for an immediate termination or filing of criminal charges against an officer when there has not been adequate time to conduct a thorough investigation of the officer's actions.
message1: Most of your claims are incorrect. The reason they are reported on more is that the severity of the reaction that minorities get by police is much worse compared to, particularly, white individuals (at least in the USA). It is easy to call someone 'resisting arrest' when the officer is almost entirely at fault for even trying to arrest someone when they wouldn't arrest them were they any other person. Claiming that they are often just resisting arrest is a claim that is entirely made up to begin with. Even if they are all resisting arrest, in no situation should an officer kill someone over that, assuming they are not in immediate danger.     Riots are entirely unrelated to this question, and riots are mostly instigated from peaceful demonstrations by false flag and black bloc incidents. If all anyone ever sees after a protest is the violence, who do you blame? Despite our police, military, and three letter agencies having a literal 200 year history of instigating and blaming minorities, political enemies, and the working class, we still for some reason want to excuse them, which is absurd.
message2: Many people in underserved communities are caught in a vicious cycle of poor education opportunities and low income opportunities.  They shouldn't be punished so severely for petty crimes.  They should be given more opportunities to get out of the cycle.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The process includes a thorough investigation before any kind of restraint or arrest of a person. This society's legal process has a basic tenet of innocent until [proven guilty. The college must treat everyone fairly and react strongly only when there is good cause to do so. To immediately act is to assume the accusation is true. The accuser could have a grudge against the accused and just made it up or maybe a past wrong by the accused against wasn't righted and the accuser did it out of spite. We need to be logical, not driven by emotions, gather evidence and listen to all sides, then decide on a course of action.
message1: Our society's legal process of "innocent until proven guilty" only applies to legal punishment such as incarceration (removal of one's constitutional right to freedom) and not to access to particular areas or private institutions. The university can make its own decisions about who is allowed on its campus, so this is not an area where "innocent until proven guilty applies." The reality is that universities far more often dismiss accusations such as this and protect the people who committed the sexual assault in order to maintain their reputation. We should be protecting the victim of the assault, not the perpetrator and certainly not the university's reputation.
message2: Although innocent until proven guilty is a legal standard in America it need not be met when safety is an issue. I agree that a proper investigation needs to be completed and it should be done as quickly as possible there is no reason that the accused could not be removed from campus quietly while that plays out. If Covid taught us anything it was that a lot of what we do in person can be done remotely. They could move the accused attacker to a remote work situation while the investigation was completed. Yes some false accusations do occur in rape cases and those should be handled swiftly and severely. But the reality is that it is an incredible small number. You can't put a lot of people at risk because of a very small number of false accusers.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.
message1: In the United States, a person is innocent of a crime UNTIL PROVEN guilty.  Removing the "alleged" perpertrator of campus sexual assault--with no proof--is placing punishment before any criminal conviction.  What is the "alleged" victim is lying--which is a frequent occurrence?    The statement that victims don't accuse sexual assault unless it's true is interesting, and also HOGWASH.  Do you recall the crazy woman going after President Biden for "assault" at the train station?
message2: I do think it's a very tough situation for the university. Safety should be the first priority. I also agree that most individuals making accusations of assault are telling the truth. However, there are exceptions to that rule. Therefore, there will be cases where someone's life could also be ruined by a false allegation. Removing them from campus would mean they would no longer be able to participate in their studies, which could be incredibly disruptive if it turns out they are innocent. The legal system can be slow and putting everything on pause indefinitely seems risky unless there is definite proof an assault took place.

issuetext: The United States should invest greater economic, military, and human resources in fighting the spread of ISIS and similar organizations around the world.
seedtext: The United States should not focus its efforts on fighting terrorist groups like ISIS. Also, it would be a more efficient use of money and resources to put it toward humanitarian aid because a little can go a long way for people who are living on less than $2 per day. issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: Hiring decisions could be made relatively blindly in order to give everyone a more equal chance.  The interviewers or individuals making a hiring decision should, when initially reading through applicants' resumes, read the relevant information with gender-identifying language (ie, names) removed if need be.  We as women are not in need of affirmative-action type policies.  I strongly believe our achievements, education, and experiences are robust enough to stand on their own.  Why would I want to get a job where afterwards co-workers whisper that I was a mandatory hire, or that they "had" to hire a woman?  I would feel uncomfortable being there.
message1: I agree, it would be a problem for the woman herself if people know she was a minority hiring. It is possible in a male-dominated industry that people hire males because they are males, or they are a family or friend, or they get hired only because they like the person. If they ignore gender, then there should be more women that are hired. It is fair to only get the best candidate, no matter who it is. I understand your position on this. I understand and agree that it might be patronizing and insulting that they would use an affirmative action style hiring system. I agree with you that they should remove gender, ethnicity, and race identifiers.    Nonetheless, I believe if a business wants to meet that quota then they should hire the female applicant over the male applicant only if the female applicant has nearly the same or better credentials. Also while skill is a very important part of an applicant, their work ethic and personality is also important when it comes to their work. I believe a more aggressive approach in hiring can bring in more female workers in the industry at a faster pace. I do believe you have a good idea when it comes to hiring people.
message2: While it's true that hiring a person "blindly" without knowledge of their sex would seem to be fair. However, women have suffered from a distinct lack of opportunities and discrimination, not to mention lower pay for the same jobs done by men, for hundreds of years. Giving them a leg up is only fair BUT only if they meet the qualifications of the position. This may be the best way to ensure an equal number of qualified women are hired rather than hiring by chance.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.

I wouldn't want there to be any doubts about my suitability for the position due to my merit, rather than my gender. Of course, people who hire for STEM positions may have unconscious (or conscious) gender biases, but I think that having a diverse hiring panel would be a better policy than implementing gender quotas.

seedtext: While I am supportive of an increase in representation of women in math, sciences, and engineering, I do not believe the best method of achieving this is to give blanket priority to female graduates over male graduates. There is no doubt that women have historically been under-represented in fields such as math and engineering, however by giving women graduates a priority over men simply because of the fact they are women could lead to less-talented candidates entering the field. I believe a better method would be to simply look at the resume/qualifications of the candidate and choose based off of who is more qualified, therefore leading to a "blind" and more objective hiring process.
message1: I am in agreement with you. To increase the representation of women in math and sciences is a good idea. However it's like using affirmative action for women. I am against that.
message2: A fair hiring process takes into consideration the fact that we do not live in a meritocracy. Given that the judging of candidates will most likely be performed by those who have privilege and access to resources that most women do not, judging the candidates on the exact same basis as one another without taking these disparities into consideration would lead to an unbalanced hiring process. In other words, there is no such thing as a truly "blind" hiring process; the most we can aim for is a fair one - not to mention considering the enhancements to the field the additional viewpoints a woman's lived experience can bring.

While I do agree that there is still a misrepresentation of women in STEM careers, I do not believe that the best and most effective way of fixing things is to make hiring women a priority. I think we need to find other ways of welcoming and supporting women in STEM careers that don't involve hiring them "just because they are women." Women need to know that they are valued and supported in these types of "non traditional" careers, and hiring solely based on gender does not solve this issue.

message1: I understand that the accused person is potentially dangerous and could commit the act again if not properly investigated. However, we must remember that the person is only being accused, and unless it can be proven with evidence that the person who committed the act did so, he should not be removed. I think it's possible he commited the act and at the same time I think he might also just being accused wrongly. The moral thing, in my opinion, is to give everyone a fair chance, and the accused person certainly deserves one.
message2: I think you make a good point that it wouldn't be very good for the victim's state of mind if the perpetrator remained on campus. On the other hand, I believe everyone should be presumed innocent until proven guilty. It may be rare, but there are people out there who wouldn't be below making things up.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: I do not feel that any candidate should be given priority in hiring decisions.  If they were given priority, this is essentially discriminating against men.  All hiring decisions should give priority to the best candidate regardless of gender.  Although I am a woman, I would want to get a job based on merit, not simply because I am a woman.  If a woman was given priority, this could lead to a less qualified candidate getting hired.  It could also lead to resentment in the workplace.
message1: That makes a lot of sense. I think at the end of the day, the company should absolutely pick the more qualified candidate, regardless of gender. However, I think there are some companies, particularly in these fields that have inherent biases towards women and automatically assume they are less qualified than men. I want to make sure whoever is conducting the hiring process truly believes that men and women are equally capable of doing this role, and that they have picked the best candidate for the position. Right now, I'm not thoroughly convinced that the hiring process is unbiased for these positions and I think women end up being at a disadvantage.
message2: I certainly agree with your point that women should not be prioritized over men unilaterally. I do think that this is wrong, but what I think  that if there are two equally qualified individuals that are vying for the same position and one is a woman, that they should get priority in the end. This is not to try to force women into a workplace, it is to attack biases directly - if there are two equally qualified people of opposite genders in a male dominated work environment, it is confronting (perhaps unconscious) biases and ensuring that a diverse workplace is being achieved by prioritizing the female candidate. I think that having a diverse work environment offers unique perspectives to issues and also paves the way for more qualified members of all groups to have equal representation in the workplace.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: As a woman in STEM, my primary consideration is feeling that I have a fair shot at any position that a man has. I don't expect any preferential treatment or gender-based affirmative action policies to compensate for past gender discrimination in STEM, though. There's a perception in some workplaces with these policies that women were only hired to fill a quota, perpetuating the gender divide. I wouldn't want there to be any doubts about my suitability for the position due to my merit, rather than my gender. Of course, people who hire for STEM positions may have unconscious (or conscious) gender biases, but I think that having a diverse hiring panel would be a better policy than implementing gender quotas.
message1: I would say something along the lines of, "I can see your point, having a woman be hired over a man, due to past discrimination, would fuel the notion that women aren't as smart, and her hire would be diminished. I don't really know how we would get more women in the position to hire, if there's a preexisting gender gap in the higher ups, and potential bias, be that conscious or not." I think I would then ask her how she thinks we should solve that hire bias.
message2: I think the term "affirmative action" often comes with a lot of baggage and it is misunderstood. For example, what you suggested of having a diverse hiring panel could be considered a form of affirmative action. I agree that if any of these policies are to be implemented, they should be done carefully so as to not make individuals feel that they are being hired to feel a quote, as opposed to being hired for their qualifications. I think the main goal of any affirmative action program is to ensure that those who are qualified (whether they be women or men) are all considered and given a fair chance.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.
message1: I understand the point taken, but we are a lawful society, and our legal system is based on innocence until proven guilty.  Why should we take one person's word over another, unless the person is caught outright doing the act, someone's accusation should not ruin someone's reputation and life.  I have been witness to many a time when someone is falsely accused of something, and by taking immediate action, it has really messed that person's life up.
message2: I understand completely what you're saying. I am well-aware that the vast majority of accusations are credible, and that false ones are few and far between. I absolutely agree that victim safety is of top priority. I think a good solution would be to adjust the schedules of both parties to ensure they are kept away from each other. It's difficult because this puts burden on the victim, but I don't think removing the alleged perpetrator before an investigation has even begun is the solution. It's a tricky situation.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: I disagree with this statement for a few reasons. Also, if the situations were not broadcast in everyone's living rooms, the general majority public who many times have no experience with these injustices, nor knowlege of how  injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere will feel like they dont have a vested interest in developing solutions to the core issues that cause crime (i.e. lack of economic development, race, community distrust etc). issuetext: The United States should invest greater economic, military, and human resources in fighting the spread of ISIS and similar organizations around the world.
seedtext: The United States should not focus its efforts on fighting terrorist groups like ISIS. It would be a much better use of resources to focus on fighting hunger, climate change, lack of education and humanitarian problems such at those in foreign, and especially low-income, countries. In the long run this would have the effect of reducing terrorism because when people have stable lives and do not worry about their day-to-day survival they are less likely to become radicalized. Also, it would be a more efficient use of money and resources to put it toward humanitarian aid because a little can go a long way for people who are living on less than $2 per day. With military and counter-terrorism funding, you just keep spending and spending and the problem doesn't go away. Note that the U.S. has been trying to "solve" terrorism in Afghanistan for over two decades and still has not "fixed" anything.
message1: I agree the United States should not be focused on fighting ISIS. We have bigger problems right now like inflation, homelessness, racial discrimination, and much more. The US should focus on fixing the unsolved issues in our country first before worrying about anything else.
message2: You are very correct that investing in a country's infrastructure, independent food supplies, education, etc. would greatly reduce the need for military intervention in the long run. However, the ISIS paramilitary group has shown that it is willing use its own population's poverty and lack of education, even using their young men as 'cannon fodder." In the short term, there is no alternative to military intervention, especially if many people would be threatened or killed. The best solution would be to do both, military intervention preceded and/or followed by investments in people's lives.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: The whole point of feminism is so that both women, men, and any other genders are treated as equals. Giving a competitive edge to women for hiring that is not based on job qualifications and skills seems counter productive to the whole point of feminism. Do I think there's a huge lack of women in STEM? Yes. Is there very likely sexism going on during hiring as it stands now? Oh yeah, definitely. I just don't ideologically agree with blanket boosting a woman's chance at hiring for simply being a women. Something like requiring a gender balance on the hiring committee like half male half female so the candidate receives a relatively more fair and balanced interview.
message1: I agree that sexism exists in the STEM field, and women are often downplayed and viewed as incapable or not more intelligent than men. There is a lack of women in STEM because it is a field that men dominate, and women should represent themselves as being treated equally as candidates for a job application.
message2: I agree with everything this person says.  However, I think it's important to recognize that women were in a position not very long ago where they couldn't work, own land, vote, or even have their own bank accounts.  While I do think that candidates should be looked at evenly no matter their gender, I also think it's important for women to have opportunities that they weren't able to have previously.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: Women have been historically underrepresented in the fields of math, science and engineering. For a good part of the 20th century, women weren't admitted into advanced University programs in these disciplines. The only way to correct this under- representation is to give priority to qualified women in hiring decisions. This presupposes that male and female candidates are equally qualified. There may be political discussion about unfair affirmative action, but there is no other viable way to correct the historical imbalance.
message1: I agree with you that women need more representation in STEM jobs. However, no matter the gender, the best person for a job should be hired. message2: While I agree that women have been historically represented in STEM fields, I think there are better ways to increase representation. The first, and likely the best way, is to encourage girls from a young age to explore these fields. A huge part of that actually requires the previous generation to eliminate any bias in this regard so as not unintentionally discourage or overlook young girls from taking part in any related interests.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.
message1: I agree that everyone has the right of presumed innocence when convicted of crimes, even if those crimes are significant.  Protection of the victims is also of the utmost importance when handling a violent crime, especially from retribution and harassment by the perpetrator.  In the case of a college campus, where the victim's schedule may keep them in potential proximity to their attacker, there must be some protocol in place to allow them to continue their studies in safety.  Whether that is house arrest for the attacker, orders of protection, or another method is dependent on extenuating circumstances.
message2: I would agree with your viewpoint.  Actions must be taken to protect both sides . Until a full investigation has taken place no removal should take place.  Both sides have laws to protect themselves.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.

If they are proven to be guilty, their time will come for their punishment.
message2: Our legal system is founded on the belief that you are innocent until proven guilty. An accusation does not mean guilt. The accused student should have the same rights as everyone else until he/she has been convicted of the crime. If the alleged victim is struggling with being on campus at that time, they can take a break, start therapy, etc.

message1: I'm not completely sure that "this is how things improve." I think that there's a difference between identifying a problem and solving it. A lot of times people conflate knowing the problem exists with knowing the solution to the problem, but they're not the same thing. For instance, climate change is real and caused by humans (the problem) but marching in the streets is not actually a solution unless it causes some sort of real change on the part of corporations. The question is, how does justifiable public anger translate to genuine, positive change? It doesn't actually do that on its own, there needs to be specific concrete steps outlined that we can take to turn anger into actions that actually improve the situation.

ISIS in particular was known for recruiting young people from middle class families in western nations. Education can be targeted not just to people in impoverished nations but, coupled with greater social acceptance, can be targeted to young people who feel alienated from society at large in western nations. These organizations are indeed terrorist in ideology and actions regardless of how they view themselves and others. Military action has proven effective in countering ISIS and al Qaeda where they had been geographically entrenched. Proving that these organizations are not divinely invincible in battle is part of the strategy for exposing the weakness of their fundamentalist religious ideology.     It is also important to expose the brutal atrocities committed by these organizations, not just against Western powers, but against civilians in areas controlled by them, including non-Muslims and Muslims they consider heretics, as well as many of their own recruits. Another important strategy is offering deprogramming therapy for prisoners captured from these organizations and those who voluntarily defect. These can be considered a form of education, in the first instance for the world stage and in the second instance for members of these organizations.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: Yes it has been overblown.  The media has portrayed these incidents to be much more common than they actually are, which has fueled the public reaction to be greater than necessary.  The public reaction has largely overlooked the fact that the majority of these incidents have been started with a suspect resisting a lawful arrest.  It has focused almost exclusively on the officer's actions and ignored the fact that nothing detrimental would have occurred had the suspect complied with the officer's orders.  There has also been rioting and destruction by some in the public that has not accomplished anything positive.  Another overreaction is in the public's call for an immediate termination or filing of criminal charges against an officer when there has not been adequate time to conduct a thorough investigation of the officer's actions.
message1: I have to disagree with you here.  I have seen too many disturbing videos with my own eyes of overly aggressive officers overstepping their authority.  I'm going to go a bit further here and say it's their culture of no accountability and immunity that allows them to behave like this.   I recently had a run in with cops in my neighborhood where they were verbally aggressive and threatening to me for simply being outside of my building when a crime happened nearby.  I had every right to be there, and they threatened to take me to jail.  I knew they had not authority to make me identify myself because I wasn't acting suspicious, but I gave in because I was scared for my safety.  I was scared they were going to arrest me and make up something that didn't happen.
message2: The fact that these situations are even occurring is terrible, media coverage or not. The destruction and rioting that you reference is not done by protesters, it is done by people who are taking advantage of peaceful protests and using them as an excuse to loot and destroy.  Those rioters do not care about the cause. They give the peaceful protesters a bad name. issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: Women have been historically underrepresented in the fields of math, science and engineering. For a good part of the 20th century, women weren't admitted into advanced University programs in these disciplines. The only way to correct this under- representation is to give priority to qualified women in hiring decisions. This presupposes that male and female candidates are equally qualified. There may be political discussion about unfair affirmative action, but there is no other viable way to correct the historical imbalance.
message1: Thank you for giving me all of this information.  However, I do not believe that regulations should be put on companies to hire women instead of men.  There are a lot of problems with enacting what you have proposed.  What if the man gives a better interview but both have similar qualifications.  Would you hire the woman in that case?
message2: Although there is a historic unbalance in the ratio of women to men in math, science, and engineering fields, today's women have the same opportunities as men to enter these fields. Society does not gain an advantage by having more women in these fields as opposed to men. Therefore no affirmative action should take place. Choosing to hire people based on gender would result in less qualified workers than those chosen by order of merit.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: While I am supportive of an increase in representation of women in math, sciences, and engineering, I do not believe the best method of achieving this is to give blanket priority to female graduates over male graduates. There is no doubt that women have historically been under-represented in fields such as math and engineering, however by giving women graduates a priority over men simply because of the fact they are women could lead to less-talented candidates entering the field. I believe a better method would be to simply look at the resume/qualifications of the candidate and choose based off of who is more qualified, therefore leading to a "blind" and more objective hiring process.
message1: I agree with this person that the system needs to hire in a more fair manner than just giving blanket priority of one group over the other. There needs to be a way to eliminate bias and by only looking at qualifications may be the right thing to do here. There also needs to be a personality assessment and I'm not sure how that can be done blindly.
message2: I agree with you that blind hiring processes should be the standard. However, I believe that it is important to consider the whole person and the culture of the organization when making hiring decisions as well. If there are equally talented men and women, it is important to try to achieve diversity and parity. It also may be helpful to consider the social differences between men and women's interests. For example, research has shown that women gravitate towards fields and ideas that contribute more to the social issues. These should be considered when assessing people's resumes and previous experience and we should try to absolve ourselves of bias towards how success is typically defined.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: I completely agree with this statement.  There is an estimated 400,000 police contacts each day with people in the United States.  The narrative you see in the media and pushed by certain groups would make you think that a large number of these contacts are adversarial up to include a high number of violence from the police towards the public.  This is simply not true.  Think about how many times you have seen officers acting inappropriately on the news.  Compare that to 400,000 each day.  The numbers just dont support this narrative.  Like in any profession you have some police officers that should not be police officers and sometimes they act like criminals.
message1: I just think that even one example of this -- especially when it's caught on video -- is one example too many. Police officers have an incredibly important job, and they need both the proper training and the proper demeanor to do it. The altercations we see on the news speak to the need for broader reforms in the policing industry, with more emphasis on deescalation and less on lethal force, and more comprehensive psychological screenings for potential and current officers.     We also need to look at police culture -- I totally agree with you that the issue is a relatively small number of cops who shouldn't be cops, but in most cases, the department knows about and protects those bad apples instead of dealing with them. Protecting the worst among them taints the entire profession. If good cops could speak out against bad ones without fear of retaliation, the system would function better and we'd all be better off.     And perhaps we should stop relying on police officers to handle situations they're not trained or prepared for, like acute mental crises. Police can't be trained to handle every single situation, so why not have other departments designed to handle the complexities of things like mental-health emergencies? It would take some pressure off officers and help avoid the kinds of stories we see where people end up shot for being mentally ill or autistic, for example.
message2: The issue is that the police departments in different parts of the country has been very lenient in the type of reprimand or charges against their "bad apples" police members. In many cases they even CONDONE these behaviors which is unacceptable. Therefore, the community needs to raise awareness and act as loud as they can so this type of behaviors is corrected and prevented. For decades there have been actions against specific group of minorities that needs to be addressed

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.
message1: I understand the concern for the alleged victim, and I agree with protecting their physical and mental safety and well-being. However, removing an accused perpetrator based solely on an accusation is a step too far, especially in a country where you are innocent until proven guilty. An accusation is not probable cause, and absent that, I can't see the right to disrupt someone's life to that extent. I would be willing to have an expedited process of getting the matter in front of a judge for a hearing, and if the judge determines there is sufficient evidence to proceed with an investigation, then steps can be taken to separate the accused from the victim, including  restraining orders, protections from abuse, and if the evidence is overwhelming and obvious, removal from campus or the local society. I would support any reasonable steps to hinder further commissions of the act or similar acts if this person is responsible, and I also think the alleged victim should have free access to whatever support services they feel are necessary.
message2: I don't think any student should be removed from a campus simply due to do an accusation. There needs to be some kind of evidence. Otherwise you are in a situation where there is no due process at all.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The reason why I think they should immediately be removed from campus to protect the victim's well being is because statistics back up that false sexual assault reports rarely exist. message1: While I understand the case for immediately removing the accused from campus, I also genuinely believe that due process needs to be followed to ensure proper protocol and investigation are followed. I am in no way saying that cases are overblown, and I believe that there are safety measures that can be put in place (i.e. removing this person from the victim's vicinity by not being allowed in dining halls, dorms, removing from any shared classes, etc) as well as supporting the accused with emotional, criminal justice, and support. However, an instant removal just reinforces the overblown criminal justice system, which often does not follow proper protocol, and does not assume the accused is innocent until proven otherwise.     This is a personal issue for me: I was sexually assaulted on my college campus, and the college was reluctant to offer help. Thankfully, I went to the local police department, which was able to guide me through the proper channels. I did not want the individual removed from campus, and was able to restore our relationship via a restorative justice process facilitated by an outside group. This was tremendous for my healing, and would never have been possible if this individual was instantly removed from campus.
message2: I understand your concern about reducing harm, but I can't say I agree. To my knowledge, false rape accusation statistics indicate the lower bound of around 10% of accusations, with others indicating it may be higher. Suspending a fundamental precept of how our society handles justice, innocent until proven guilty, is not the answer. We need to ensure we foster an environment where innocent parties are not unjustly punished.

The 9/11 attacks proved that no matter how much money we throw at the problem of international terrorism. While I do not feel as though we should be entirely reactionary in our response to national security, I feel as though we are neglecting more pressing matters. The billions of dollars that we spend on our military have made us a global superpower, but we are not at war with other nations, we are at war with ideals. Nations and governments rise and fall, but ideals can live on indefinitely. While in the past, when the world faced such crises as the rise of Nazis or Communism, we needed to pour as much money as possible towards fighting these evils; however this is no longer the case. War as a whole has changed. Wars are no longer fought on battlefields with uniformed nations against one another. Wars are waged against organizations of loosely networked radicals. As long as an extremist has a heartbeat, their warped views will inevitably live on to be passed on to whoever they can proselytize to. The rise, fall, and subsequent resurrection of civilian-led terrorist organizations such as ISIS and the Taliban have proved this. I do agree that the money we have invested into our military has helped many people in other countries, as we have been able to protect innocent lives in countries where the government has collapsed, such as in Iraq and Afghanistan. Our military has helped many people live more prosperous lives and has brought democracy to places that would have never been seen otherwise. Thanks to our military spending we have changed many lives for the better, and recent events in Afghanistan have shown that our presence there made a difference and helped save countless lives.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.

The solution would be continue to push women in to STEM fields. Among older populations there is generally less interest in STEM but as the population gets younger, there is more of an interest. The gap is not due to sexism (on a large scale) but the amount of women who have worked to be in these fields. This number will only continue to grow as the younger population moves in.
message2: There actually is a way to increase representation of women in math and science fields and it isn't through just giving women a job over a more qualified man. This is incredibly unfair. I wouldn't want there to be any doubts about my suitability for the position due to my merit, rather than my gender. issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process. The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus. issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: As a woman in STEM, my primary consideration is feeling that I have a fair shot at any position that a man has. I don't expect any preferential treatment or gender-based affirmative action policies to compensate for past gender discrimination in STEM, though. There's a perception in some workplaces with these policies that women were only hired to fill a quota, perpetuating the gender divide. I wouldn't want there to be any doubts about my suitability for the position due to my merit, rather than my gender. Of course, people who hire for STEM positions may have unconscious (or conscious) gender biases, but I think that having a diverse hiring panel would be a better policy than implementing gender quotas.
message1: I think the term "affirmative action" often comes with a lot of baggage and it is misunderstood, so I agree with you that programs that further perpetuate a gender divide are not good. However, I think the term or these policies can be applied more broadly. For example, what you suggested of having a diverse hiring panel could be considered a form of affirmative action. I agree that if any of these policies are to be implemented, they should be done carefully so as to not make individuals feel that they are being hired to feel a quote, as opposed to being hired for their qualifications. However, I acknowledge that, as a man, I am one step removed from this and that the voices of women should be just as equally heard. I think the main goal of any affirmative action program is to ensure that those who are qualified (whether they be women or men) are all considered and given a fair chance.
message2: I hear your arguments, and they are valid.  A diverse hiring board is essential and should also be implemented. There are those that will make comments and think that women are only hired due to an inclusive hiring policy.  And those people are exactly why that policy still needs to be in place.
