I'd like for them to answer the more difficult and confrontational prompt actually given of should men be put DOWN in order for those women to be put UP with a biased hiring process?

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: I do not feel that any candidate should be given priority in hiring decisions.  If they were given priority, this is essentially discriminating against men.  All hiring decisions should give priority to the best candidate regardless of gender.  Although I am a woman, I would want to get a job based on merit, not simply because I am a woman.  If a woman was given priority, this could lead to a less qualified candidate getting hired.  It could also lead to resentment in the workplace.
message1: While I see where you are coming from, I disagree on some points. I feel that diversity in the workplace in incredibly important. If hiring a woman means the diversity happens, then I see no problem with that. I can see how it might lead to a less qualified candidate. However, as long as the candidates are vetted properly, I still see no issue.
message2: That makes a lot of sense. I think at the end of the day, the company should absolutely pick the more qualified candidate, regardless of gender. However, I think there are some companies, particularly in these fields that have inherent biases towards women and automatically assume they are less qualified than men. I want to make sure whoever is conducting the hiring process truly believes that men and women are equally capable of doing this role, and that they have picked the best candidate for the position.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: I believe increasing representation of a majority of the population is imperative. One way is to decrease barriers of systemic barriers such as cultural norms around gender identity. Furthermore this extends to compensation and fair obligations  of decency to all people. I believe creating a way to increase underrepresented populations to differing fields greatly increases the growth of that industry and the growth of the population it is serving.
message1: I slightly agree. I do think women are underrepresented in most "high profile" fields. However, I don't think women should be given priority simply based on gender. I think everyone with the appropriate qualifications should be considered for a position, regardless of gender, race, etc. Women or any minority should not get a job just because they are minorities - that wouldn't be fair either.
message2: I can understand your position but I don't believe in giving anyone priority with regard to hiring decisions sloely based on their gender. The strongest candidate for the job should be selected no matter their race, sexual orientation, or their gender. I agree there are benefits to increasing representation of a majority of the population but some people do not subscribe to the thought of there only being binary genders so how would this affect your opinion on the issue?

issuetext: The United States should invest greater economic, military, and human resources in fighting the spread of ISIS and similar organizations around the world.
seedtext: The United States should invest in the people who live in the country. War and military is not something we are struggling with. The American people need free education, more jobs and healthcare. The government spends trillions on things that are not important instead of using it for helpful things such as healthcare which is needed when millions do not have healthcare. Trillions are spent on companies who already have billions of dollars and have tax breaks when that money could be used for free college to help students have a career and not have to struggle with a horrible job.
message1: I agree with many of the points that you expressed. We must give people in our country opportunities to better themselves. Education is a must. We must provide better paying jobs for those that choose technical fields. However I remember after graduating high school 9/11 took place. Isis and the Taliban wreaked havoc. I knew many peers that joined military. I know many of them sacrificed their lives to protect our great land. We must not forget this. We must stay vigilant. We should prioritize funding to continue this war on terrorism.
message2: I agree that spending money to try and diffuse radical groups around the world is a good idea. I don't agree with the literal laundry list of things you mentioned after that. I believe our government should work in our interest when it comes to domestic and international spending. But when you start talking about free education and free healthcare then I think we are outside of the responsibility of government. I do believe government can incentivize and subsidize those activities but I think it is up to individual citizens to provide for themselves.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be given due process and a fair trial before anything is done. Assuming guilt before a fair process is the right way. If someone accused me of a crime its my right to be able to defend myself, especially if I did not the crime. If I was assumed guilty before I had the chance, that would be a double crime. Due process needs to be the priority in cases of sexual assault and accusations. Women are not to be believed simply because they are women. Men lie, women lie, everybody is capable of lying.  This idea that women are not capable of lying is a made up idea and if anybody has ever known any women they fully know that women and men are both capable of lying. doesn't matter what gender you are. all people are capable of lies.
message1: I think that sounds about right, however it's probably important to separate the two and make sure the can't come into contact easily while things are sorted out. I think once they are separated an investigation can then take place to see what is going on. The accused shouldn't be overly punished or restricted too much until things are looked into.
message2: I definitely see where you are coming from and I agree that people do lie all of the time. I agree with due process happening on campus, but I would go ahead and contact the actual police about a sexual assault. It's possible that the victim may be able to get a restraining order, and that is not something the university can issue or deny. The university can investigate things from there (as well as the police). I understand that justice may not be served, but I think that believing victims of crime is important.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: I disagree with this statement for a few reasons. The public reaction has had the benefit of forcing the issues of police misconduct which generations of Americans have experienced with no justice or protection to the forefront of public policy in the country.  Without public pressure and a serious acknowedgement of unqeual protection under the law , these crimes against minority communities would continue to be swept under the rug. Also, if the situations were not broadcast in everyone's living rooms, the general majority public who many times have no experience with these injustices, nor knowlege of how  injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere will feel like they dont have a vested interest in developing solutions to the core issues that cause crime (i.e. lack of economic development, race, community distrust etc). If the instances of police brutality and incarceration were being perpetuated on the majority class there would be no end to the public confrontation.
message1: I learned that the vast majority of the populace is complacent and unless it's put in their faces they won't demand change or fight against injustice.
message2: I totally feel like you have brought some very valuable things on the table. People throughout the world definitely deserve better, I do not think a color or even an accent is enough to criminalize somebody. I do agree with you to an extent, but at the end of the day people are going to treat others based on their individual instead of race economical standing. Public pressure is really important because it highlights what the majority of the people want. This helps minorities as well as other individuals to be able to advance their social standing in order to have a better career and future.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Not only should the person who has been accused of sexual assault be immediately removed from campus, but should be removed from society. No one can justify allowing someone to continue to terrorize others. Unfortunately, we have to wait for the wheels of justice to turn to put away predators. The horrors that victims face just knowing that the predator may still be out there can cause all sorts of stress and post traumatic stress. The sooner that we can get someone who is convicted and proven to be dangerous off of the street, the better for all of us in society.
message1: I typically agree if we are sure the person is in fact a predator. I believe victims, always. However, these people that commit sexually assault are usually NOT brought to justice as evidence is typically weak in these cases. It is unfortunate and I wish more could be done. I wish schools did more to help out the victims, but they usually try to remain neutral, which causes more problems for the victims.
message2: Soooo,  your position is that an accusation is enough to punish and stigmatize someone for an unproven allegation?  Really? What about the rights of the falsely accused?  Fortunately, we have the wheels of justice to determine if punishment is required. Protecting the rights of someone who is not yet "convicted or proven" will make a better society for all of us.  Hope I set you straight.  You're welcome.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The reason why I think they should immediately be removed from campus to protect the victim's well being is because statistics back up that false sexual assault reports rarely exist. It is much more easy to just believe the victim instead of the alleged abuser. This is important because we want the victim to feel safe while they are trying to recover and continue on with their education. If you don't do this it'll send a message that you're okay with it. That's not what we should do.
message1: I agree with you now, however I do want to bring up an important note. I believe that you are right in saying that there are rarely false sexual assault reports, due to the severity in consequences if they are false. I do think that in the interest of fairness, that there should be some sort of investigation period in which the individual is innocent until proven guilty. While this person should not necessarily remain in the area of the victim, they should be given some sort of accommodation to attend classes (virtually for example) off campus, until proven guilty. False sexual assault reports can tear innocent individuals' lives apart in the extremely rare chance that it is false.
message2: In all fairness, what happened to innocent until proven guilty?  This society is quick to label people without knowing all of the facts. Maybe we should take a good look at the accuser of this horrific crime and then do a side by side comparision.  Let's think this out before we make an enemy out of a potentinally innocent person.

issuetext: The United States should invest greater economic, military, and human resources in fighting the spread of ISIS and similar organizations around the world.
seedtext: The United States should not focus its efforts on fighting terrorist groups like ISIS. It would be a much better use of resources to focus on fighting hunger, climate change, lack of education and humanitarian problems such at those in foreign, and especially low-income, countries. In the long run this would have the effect of reducing terrorism because when people have stable lives and do not worry about their day-to-day survival they are less likely to become radicalized. Also, it would be a more efficient use of money and resources to put it toward humanitarian aid because a little can go a long way for people who are living on less than $2 per day. With military and counter-terrorism funding, you just keep spending and spending and the problem doesn't go away. Note that the U.S. has been trying to "solve" terrorism in Afghanistan for over two decades and still has not "fixed" anything.
message1: Although I do agree that hunger is a major problem in the world today, I respectfully disagree with your opinion. If the United States doesn't continue to grow its military and fight these terrorists, the world as we know it could change drastically. If these terrorist groups are able to spread they will become bigger and stronger which is a threat to America and the world.
message2: This argument does even make sense, these are two different budgets in the United States. Fighting terrorism saves everyone in the world. Yes, fighting hunger and giving more foreign aid will help, but terrorism is bigger, because it creates hunger and famine around the world. More and more people are displaced due to terrorism. I understand the argument, but some of these countries have been poor longer than the Afghan war. If you think sending money to these corrupt governments will help, maybe they need to read more about these countries.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Not only should the person who has been accused of sexual assault be immediately removed from campus, but should be removed from society. The horrors that victims face just knowing that the predator may still be out there can cause all sorts of stress and post traumatic stress. message1: I understand that it is stressful for victims when the accused is not immediately removed from campus. We should do everything possible to protect the victims of sexual assault. If we were to immediately remove everyone accused, then this may lead to many innocent people being accused just so that they would be removed from campus. This would then cause undo stress and harm to them as well. Instead of immediately removing the accused, we can have support for the accuser while the wheels of justice are put in motion to deal with the guilty party.
message2: I do understand what you are saying and you make a fair point. My main concern would be removing someone based on an accusation rather than evidence. Only a small percentage of accusations have been proven to be fabricated, but they still happen. It wouldn't be fair to ruin someone's life without proof.

issuetext: The United States should invest greater economic, military, and human resources in fighting the spread of ISIS and similar organizations around the world.

message1: One of the reasons why organizations such as ISIS exist in the first place is because the US is continuously interferes in the political process of countries for the purpose of advancing their own interests at the expense of the people who live in those countries. issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: The whole point of feminism is so that both women, men, and any other genders are treated as equals. Giving a competitive edge to women for hiring that is not based on job qualifications and skills seems counter productive to the whole point of feminism. Do I think there's a huge lack of women in STEM? Yes. Is there very likely sexism going on during hiring as it stands now? Oh yeah, definitely. I just don't ideologically agree with blanket boosting a woman's chance at hiring for simply being a women. Something like requiring a gender balance on the hiring committee like half male half female so the candidate receives a relatively more fair and balanced interview.
message1: It's important to consider that the problem currently is that while more women are entering STEM fields, they often hit a glass ceiling in advancement of their careers. In fact, even female dominated STEM fields end up having hardly any female representation at the upper levels. The extra higher incentives are not an advantage, but a leveling of the playing field in historically male dominated fields. I understand that this feels unfair but it's just making things actually equal which is the point of feminism as you pointed out.
message2: You have answered the question and undermined your point with your own words. There is a massive under-representation of women in stem, and these kinds of policies are specifically to boost hiring women to improve the fields for those women and future women. It remains clear from levels of women in STEM fields that we cannot trust the organizations to move beyond the old boy's club. And how many women still have to deal with massive sexism in the field if they even get hired? Give women priority in getting hired, and in promotions, and they can work to smooth out changes and shift away from policies like hiring priorities.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.

message1: I understand your point and I agree. I think it is important to include women in different areas of work, it is a fact that they are qualified for any type of work. I think it is important to highlight that it doesn't matter if you are a woman or a man, the main thing is your knowledge and dedication to the job.

message1: While I understand your reasoning, the basis of law is that a person is presumed innocent until found guilty.  If you immediately remove a person from campus for an allegation, and before the investigation into it, then you are presuming they are guilty.  I don't think that is a fair assumption.  An investigation into the matter should occur before any action is taken.
message2: I understand that there are very few false sexual assault accusations, but the investigative process needs to play out before people are removed from campus. I don't believe anyone should be removed from campus until an investigation is completed. An accusation shouldn't be enough to get someone removed from campus.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Having someone immediately removed from a campus just because someone made an accusation against them is a little ridiculous. This type of precedent sets up mainly male students but could also set up female students as well to be in a position where they are in constant fear. This fear would come from knowing that if they say the wrong thing or act the wrong way they could be taken off campus without proof. Now if there is immediate proof then I completely agree that they should be kicked out, however without a good amount of evidence to prove something happened then I think kicking the students off campus should wait.
message1: I think that you make a good point that we shouldn't immediately jump to the most drastic of circumstances right away without proof. However, I would say that there should be attempts to ensure the safety of the victim by separating them from contact with the alleged wrongdoer, even if that doesn't mean removing the perpetrator from campus right away. If there is proof, then I also agree the perpetrator should be removed ASAP.
message2: Not kicking the person off campus creates an even greater fear - the fear that someone can assault you and be allowed to be near you during the investigation. It's ridiculous to leave an accused assaulter around the victim. Not only is it traumatic, it allows the assaulter to potentially threaten the victim further.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: As a woman in STEM, my primary consideration is feeling that I have a fair shot at any position that a man has. I don't expect any preferential treatment or gender-based affirmative action policies to compensate for past gender discrimination in STEM, though. There's a perception in some workplaces with these policies that women were only hired to fill a quota, perpetuating the gender divide. I wouldn't want there to be any doubts about my suitability for the position due to my merit, rather than my gender. Of course, people who hire for STEM positions may have unconscious (or conscious) gender biases, but I think that having a diverse hiring panel would be a better policy than implementing gender quotas.
message1: I totally agree with you. I think women should be hired based on their own abilities rather than external factors such as their gender, race, ethnicity, and etc. But I still feel that having a quota will help to reinforce the idea of women have fair position in STEM. This is only a starting point. Because as you said, people may have unconscious biases against women in STEM, if they work in HR, they may skip applications from female applicants. Having a quota kind of enforce these people to look through every application. But I do admit that there's a con with having a quota which is women are not competing with men but women for the quota when looking for job, but I still feel like the quota is a very good starting point for eradicating (hopefully) gender biases, and once it becomes a norm, company can put out other hiring policies.
message2: I hear your arguments, and they are valid.  A diverse hiring board is essential and should also be implemented.  However, the playing field must still be leveled for women and minorities until such a time that attitudes in this country change.  There are those that will make comments and think that women are only hired due to an inclusive hiring policy.  And those people are exactly why that policy still needs to be in place.  I will not internalize their misogyny.

seedtext: The reason why I think they should immediately be removed from campus to protect the victim's well being is because statistics back up that false sexual assault reports rarely exist. It is much more easy to just believe the victim instead of the alleged abuser. This is important because we want the victim to feel safe while they are trying to recover and continue on with their education. If you don't do this it'll send a message that you're okay with it. That's not what we should do.
message1: I think that the alleged perpetrator should not be immediately removed from campus. After all, the justice system still follows an "innocent until proven guilty" principle. There should be a proper investigation into the facts and circumstances before any punishment is given. There can be other ways to protect the victim during this period of time, such as a restraining order that prevents the alleged perpetrator from being near the victim.
message2: I agree with you that there are very few false sexual assault accusations. However, the investigative process needs to play out before people are removed from campus. I don't believe anyone should be removed from campus until an investigation is completed. An accusation shouldn't be enough to get someone removed from campus. For instance, police can't arrest somebody on sexual assault charges without probable cause and for that reason, college campuses shouldn't remove alleged sexual assault perpetrators until they have probable cause (e.g., a completed investigation.)

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: While there have been some outright excessive force issues, some unfortunately resulting in the death of minorities at the hands of police, I feel that social media has contributed to the problem by repeatedly replaying these incidents while doing nothing to improve dialogue and truly analyze the data on police use of excessive force against minorities.
message1: I agree that social media has brought police brutality to the attention of millions of people, however I do not think this is a bad thing. Even one incident is too many, and by posting it on social media, this will hopefully make police officers stop and think before using excessive force. It would make many people feel safer in the world if there was less brutality from police.
message2: Although I agree that social media has played a large role in the increased focus on police violence towards minorities, I think it is a key role. Police violence has been occurring for decades, but social media finally makes it easier to bring to light. It makes it harder to ignore the situation and sparks an important conversation about who is safe in our country.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: Historically, women have not had access to higher education, and for those women that do, sexism has oftentimes prohibited them from getting well-paid positions. Math, sciences, and engineering has historically been a male-dominated field. It has proved to be difficult for women to be in these environments, due to less female-friendly work environments and more stories of sexual assault. In addition, hiring decisions make it less likely that male-dominated spaces would hire a woman with similar credentials to a man. In order to increase representation and make these workplaces more equitable, women with relevant degrees should be given priority over men.
message1: I agree that hiring women over men would make the statistics more even in the workplace.  However, I do not feel that this would represent true equality.  I don't believe that anyone should be given higher consideration for jobs based on sex.  That ideal goes for men as well as women.  It seems to me, that the only true equality would come from hiring a person based on their ability to do a particular job.  Whether they are a man or a woman should have no weight on who gets the job.
message2: I can completely understand your point of view however I respectfully disagree. Women have fought very hard for equality and giving us a leg up isn't equal treatment. Perhaps people in the STEM industry should be hired completely on their qualifications rather than their gender. If we could take gender completely off of the resume that would be the most fair and equal way to hire someone.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: Women have been historically underrepresented in the fields of math, science and engineering. For a good part of the 20th century, women weren't admitted into advanced University programs in these disciplines. The only way to correct this under- representation is to give priority to qualified women in hiring decisions. This presupposes that male and female candidates are equally qualified. There may be political discussion about unfair affirmative action, but there is no other viable way to correct the historical imbalance.
message1: What is the definition of equally qualified ? Restoring equality should be done based solely on qualifications and skills (that a person can work on) rather than inherited physical traits that they can not change. This is especially more important in the STEM field where brain matters more than physical traits
message2: Why is the "under=representation" a problem? issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.

I believe a better method would be to simply look at the resume/qualifications of the candidate and choose based off of who is more qualified, therefore leading to a "blind" and more objective hiring process.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.
message1: You are right, a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. But the accused should be innocent until proven guilty because accusers can lie to ruin the accused life just for the fun. Still, even if the accused is proven innocent the accuser will still have ruined the accused life.
message2: While I agree that in our judicial system, the rights of the accused are very important and the accused should not be found guilty without a fair trial, a university is not a court of law.  A university, as an institution, has an obligation to protect the safety and well being of its students.  Especially given how incredibly rare false accusations of rape or sexual assault are, I believe the university has an obligation to act to remove the person accused of rape or sexual assault in order to protect the safety and emotional well being of the victim.  To do otherwise is to create an unsafe environment for the victim and to fail in its obligation to protect the safety and well being of students.  In the highly unlikely event that the accused person is found not to have committed the rape or sexual assault (and that's seriously highly unlikely given how rare false accusations are and how its far more likely that rapists and sexual assaulters get away with their crimes than for false accusations to happen) the falsely accused individual can then be allowed back to campus and have their tuition refunded for the time that they were not allowed to attend.

It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.
message1: I agree that the accused has rights as well. They should have the opportunity to share their side and prove their innocence. I just feel that removing them temporarily from campus until an investigation has been completed is in everyone's, including their, best interest.
message2: I see your point and I understand where you are coming from. However, this I believe is also for the good of the accused as well as the accuser. What if sympathizers of the accused decide to "teach him/her" a lesson and in the process harm them. I believe the accuser would not want that on their conscience. For both their safety, physical and emotional, respectively, the accuser should be barred from campus until investigations are done. Compromising with your points though, I believe the accused should be advised on this and take his or her opinion into consideration.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: Women have been historically underrepresented in the fields of math, science and engineering. The only way to correct this under- representation is to give priority to qualified women in hiring decisions. This presupposes that male and female candidates are equally qualified. issuetext: The United States should invest greater economic, military, and human resources in fighting the spread of ISIS and similar organizations around the world.
seedtext: The United States should not focus its efforts on fighting terrorist groups like ISIS. It would be a much better use of resources to focus on fighting hunger, climate change, lack of education and humanitarian problems such at those in foreign, and especially low-income, countries. In the long run this would have the effect of reducing terrorism because when people have stable lives and do not worry about their day-to-day survival they are less likely to become radicalized. Also, it would be a more efficient use of money and resources to put it toward humanitarian aid because a little can go a long way for people who are living on less than $2 per day. With military and counter-terrorism funding, you just keep spending and spending and the problem doesn't go away. Note that the U.S. has been trying to "solve" terrorism in Afghanistan for over two decades and still has not "fixed" anything.
message1: I believe we agree and have the same end goal but slightly disagree with not spending money fighting terrorism. I also agree with you, that those who are being controlled, abused, murdered have to be given the tools to take care of themselves.  Tools such as enough food to survive, the ability to make decisions for them and their families, clean water, safe environment to live in and the ability to have a good education.  To give people resources but not protect them will not work either.  Those who are controlling and abusing, such as "Isis" will just come into these communities and take all the food, money, etc that you send.  They will kidnap and/or kill the people you send to educate and provide services to others. issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: Historically, women have not had access to higher education, and for those women that do, sexism has oftentimes prohibited them from getting well-paid positions. Math, sciences, and engineering has historically been a male-dominated field. It has proved to be difficult for women to be in these environments, due to less female-friendly work environments and more stories of sexual assault. In addition, hiring decisions make it less likely that male-dominated spaces would hire a woman with similar credentials to a man. In order to increase representation and make these workplaces more equitable, women with relevant degrees should be given priority over men.
message1: While I appreciate the inequality of many workplaces, the solution to sexism is not more sexism. Men and women are equally gifted and capable at nearly every task and career path. It is therefore important to see to it that we hire only on merit and not on immutable characteristics such as gender or race. I oppose biased hiring and I oppose affirmative action whether it be for past race or gender discrimination. I support meritorious female empowerment, not the government passing laws to give women their own power.
message2: While I completely agree with some of the points you made, specifically the stories from the work place scaring women away and having equity in the workplace, I do not agree with the statement that women should be given priority over men. I think something that should be taken into account is how many women are going to school for this compared to men? How many women are actively applying for jobs in these fields compared to men? I do not think it's right to hire a MAN over a WOMAN due to gender, and I also don't think it's right to hire a woman over a man due to gender. To me, the gender of a person should be irrelevant to the decision of being hired. I believe we should do things like increased benefits such as maternity leave and remote work, so women are more willing to go into these job fields and know their hard work won't be interrupted if they decide to have kids. The main point of your argument that I agree with is making the field more attractive to women candidates. The best things we can do is make them feel safe going into these fields in school, and encouraging it from that perspective. Once more and more women see they can still go in these fields, they can still have kids and prioritize their home life when needed, then I believe more women will do that.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. message1: While I agree that in our judicial system, the rights of the accused are very important and the accused should not be found guilty without a fair trial, a university is not a court of law.  A university, as an institution, has an obligation to protect the safety and well being of its students.  Especially given how incredibly rare false accusations of rape or sexual assault are, the university has an obligation to act to remove the person accused of rape or sexual assault in order to protect the safety and emotional well being of the victim.  To do otherwise is to create an unsafe environment for the victim and to fail in its obligation to protect the safety and well being of students.  In the highly unlikely event that the accused person is found not to have committed the rape or sexual assault (and that's seriously highly unlikely given how rare false accusations are and how its far more likely that rapists and sexual assaulters get away with their crimes than for false accusations to happen) the falsely accused individual can then be allowed back to campus and have their tuition refunded for the time that they were not allowed to attend.
message2: I agree that the rights of the accused should be protected until they are proven to be guilty. While sexual assault accusations should always be taken seriously, I believe that there are sometimes cases of false accusation. Its definitely a good idea for precautions to be set in place to protect the accuser, such as placing a restraining order or provided additional security. However, I agree that it would be unfair to ban the accused from campus if they haven't been proved guilty, because there is still the possibility that they are innocent.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: Yes it has been overblown.  The media has portrayed these incidents to be much more common than they actually are, which has fueled the public reaction to be greater than necessary.  The public reaction has largely overlooked the fact that the majority of these incidents have been started with a suspect resisting a lawful arrest.  It has focused almost exclusively on the officer's actions and ignored the fact that nothing detrimental would have occurred had the suspect complied with the officer's orders.  There has also been rioting and destruction by some in the public that has not accomplished anything positive. issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

Also, if the situations were not broadcast in everyone's living rooms, the general majority public who many times have no experience with these injustices, nor knowlege of how  injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere will feel like they dont have a vested interest in developing solutions to the core issues that cause crime (i.e. lack of economic development, race, community distrust etc). issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.

There may be political discussion about unfair affirmative action, but there is no other viable way to correct the historical imbalance.
message1: Women want to have equal rights.  The only way to have equal rights is for the best person to receive the job.  Women should not get special treatment for a job, just because they are a woman. The same goes for any gender. The merits of the person should help them get a job, not their gender.
message2: Simply hiring women over men in the workplace — simply because they are women — could cause a backlash and make women feel that they were hired simply because of their sex. They also may not garner the respect they would otherwise get and deserve. The historic imbalance between men and women in tech should be addressed at the education level, not at the level of the workplace.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.

message1: While I agree that the United States needs to be safe for its citizens, I do not feel as though we need to act as the "world's police." We have dedicated far too much money to military funding in the past and have neglected many of the more pressing matters we face within our own borders. The 9/11 attacks proved that no matter how much money we throw at the problem of international terrorism. While I do not feel as though we should be entirely reactionary in our response to national security, I feel as though we are neglecting more pressing matters. The billions of dollars that we spend on our military have made us a global superpower, but we are not at war with other nations, we are at war with ideals. Nations and governments rise and fall, but ideals can live on indefinitely. War as a whole has changed. Wars are no longer fought on battlefields with uniformed nations against one another. Wars are waged against organizations of loosely networked radicals. As long as an extremist has a heartbeat, their warped views will inevitably live on to be passed on to whoever they can proselytize to. The rise, fall, and subsequent resurrection of civilian-led terrorist organizations such as ISIS and the Taliban have proved this.
message2: I agree with you that a lot of people think that the United States should provide a defense for them and ensure peace worldwide. I have a slightly different way of thinking about it: Sometimes it is more prudent to stay out of certain worldwide affairs for fear of escalation. I agree that our military and defense spending and advancements have allowed us to be the best military in the world. However, I think that should be more of a defensive position, first and foremost. I agree with the idea though.

seedtext: Yes it has been overblown.  The media has portrayed these incidents to be much more common than they actually are, which has fueled the public reaction to be greater than necessary. It has focused almost exclusively on the officer's actions and ignored the fact that nothing detrimental would have occurred had the suspect complied with the officer's orders.  There has also been rioting and destruction by some in the public that has not accomplished anything positive.  Another overreaction is in the public's call for an immediate termination or filing of criminal charges against an officer when there has not been adequate time to conduct a thorough investigation of the officer's actions.
message1: Crimes happen everyday and people are arrested everyday and all people have the right to be treated in the same manner.  We have certain rights and some people are granted these rights while others are not just based on the color of their skin.  We all have biases and prejudices but they have no place in the criminal justice system.  Police need to be trained to handle these situations uniformly no matter the race of the suspect and treat all people the same.  The publics reaction should and has been outrage and whether this has happened once or a million times we should all be working to correct it.
message2: I would disagree with the above response. I do not think that the public reaction has been overblown, rather I believe the public is finally being exposed to the burdens minorities face when interacting with law enforcement. Statistics show that minority groups are clearly targeted by law enforcement in the US, and it is important to bring awareness to this issue so that we as a nation can take steps in the right direction. While there are some instances where the victim is not complying with initial requests from officers, that is most likely because minority groups carry generational trauma related to violent interactions with the police. I would also argue that when people are calling for an officer to be prosecuted that is largely because they tend to have a long list of previous complaints and a deep pattern has already been established.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: As a woman in STEM, my primary consideration is feeling that I have a fair shot at any position that a man has. I don't expect any preferential treatment or gender-based affirmative action policies to compensate for past gender discrimination in STEM, though. There's a perception in some workplaces with these policies that women were only hired to fill a quota, perpetuating the gender divide. I wouldn't want there to be any doubts about my suitability for the position due to my merit, rather than my gender. Of course, people who hire for STEM positions may have unconscious (or conscious) gender biases, but I think that having a diverse hiring panel would be a better policy than implementing gender quotas.

I would then ask her how she thinks we should solve the potential bias when hiring.
message2: You raise a good point about the need for a diverse hiring panel. Even though this would help in getting more women hired into stem, ingherent bias may stlll be present both in male and female panel members that skews favor towards hiring men. For this reason, I feel a diverse hiring panel AND quotas towards hiring women into STEM are important.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.
message1: The rights of the accused are important as well. The victim should be protected as much as possible. The removal of the accused from the campus is a step in the right direction. The situation needs to be solved as quickly as possible.
message2: I agree with aspects of this point of view, especially with the points made about the rights of the accused versus the rights of victims. There seems to a lot of pressure from society to reject the claims of innocence from an accused person, which is not exactly fair. However, the point remains that safety must be maintained, so it is up to the discretion of the university to determine the course of action while an investigation is performed. However, a person should not be dismissed permanently simply because they have been accused.

message1: Healthcare is a selfless field and I applaud you for taking care of all of us humans. It must not be easy and I would not be able to do that. I will say this: I would always rather have the best person for the job, regardless if it is a woman or a man, especially when we're talking about matters of life and death, like what you do in your job. message2: I understand that it is more common to see male doctors than female doctors. And ideally, yes, it would be great to see more women in certain careers. You said that we should empower women in STEM fields, but how? How could we empower them without being unfair to men? Frankly, I don't believe that women are being discouraged from the STEM field. There aren't a lot of women in STEM careers because women themselves are choosing not to go into those fields. You might think, "Oh, well that's because they only see men in that field and might feel discouraged." I'm sorry, but then that's THEIR problem. I am a woman and I don't feel any pressure from men to stay out of certain fields. Women are allowed to go into whatever field they want, most are just choosing not to go into certain fields. This is an unpopular opinion, but I believe it's the same with race. People sometimes say, "I wish there were more non-white teachers or politicians." There aren't many people of color in those fields, not because they're purposely being excluded or held back, but because they're not entering those fields. And if someone chooses not to embrace an interest of theirs and going into a specific field just because they feel like it's flooded with men or with white people, then that's on THEM. Nobody is purposely holding back women or minorities in a certain field. As a Hispanic woman, I just don't feel that. A lot of people will disagree with me, but I'm just saying what I've observed and experienced.

seedtext: Historically, women have not had access to higher education, and for those women that do, sexism has oftentimes prohibited them from getting well-paid positions. In addition, hiring decisions make it less likely that male-dominated spaces would hire a woman with similar credentials to a man. In order to increase representation and make these workplaces more equitable, women with relevant degrees should be given priority over men.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: As a woman in STEM, my primary consideration is feeling that I have a fair shot at any position that a man has. I don't expect any preferential treatment or gender-based affirmative action policies to compensate for past gender discrimination in STEM, though. There's a perception in some workplaces with these policies that women were only hired to fill a quota, perpetuating the gender divide. I wouldn't want there to be any doubts about my suitability for the position due to my merit, rather than my gender. Of course, people who hire for STEM positions may have unconscious (or conscious) gender biases, but I think that having a diverse hiring panel would be a better policy than implementing gender quotas.
message1: Women are as capable as men in STEM. I fully understand your concerns and I hope this unconscious gender biases may slowly disappear. As a man, I hope I can do more to help alleviate this issue. It is not just women's job to get rid of this gender biases. We have to work together so we can provide a better future for both men and women. I know many super qualified women work in STEM and their performance is actually better than men's. Therefore, I have no doubt that women are as capable as men in STEM.
message2: Wile I agree that a diverse hiring panel would be helpful in increasing the representation of women in STEM, I think giving preference to women over men, given the same set of qualifications, would more effectively close the gender gap in STEM. I know the word "quota" rubs people the wrong way, and I can understand that - it rubs me the wrong way. However, establishing some sort of system or algorithm that prioritizes hiring women over men - again, when their qualifications are the same, would remove unconscious, internalized bias from the decision making process, and better increase women's representation in STEM. This need not be a permanent solution. Exposure to women in the work field over time would naturally help reduce hiring bias.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

The military can focus on threats of outside forces, while we focus internally on aiding those around us and those in need of help. We are doing a disservice if we do not take care of our home before worrying about others.

We are prosperous and wealthy and have the means to pursue more than one strategy or focus on a single issue at a time. I can't think of any nation in the world who is not at least somewhat engaged in and dependent on the global economy as it has evolved to date. Every nation has domestic issues and every nation has international interests and economic dependencies. Both have to be addressed at all times. We are not a standalone nation with no outside economic interests. We have alliances with many nations in Europe and Asia who increasingly face threats from Russia, China, North Korea and terrorist groups who recognize no authority whatsoever. As the global economy goes, so goes the United States. International trade is domestic trade. It is true that funding issues require agreement between domestic and international problems that need to be solved but those debates have always been there since the country was founded. If our government is only capable of handling one problem at a time then we have already failed.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: While I am supportive of an increase in representation of women in math, sciences, and engineering, I do not believe the best method of achieving this is to give blanket priority to female graduates over male graduates. There is no doubt that women have historically been under-represented in fields such as math and engineering, however by giving women graduates a priority over men simply because of the fact they are women could lead to less-talented candidates entering the field. I believe a better method would be to simply look at the resume/qualifications of the candidate and choose based off of who is more qualified, therefore leading to a "blind" and more objective hiring process.
message1: I think that woman need the support on a societal level. Doing more things to actually address misogyny and the very real dangers that women face on a daily basis from men would be more impactful. If we give women more jobs in a field but the men in the field are still allowed to treat them poorly, is that really that helpful? If we give woman priority, will that actually solve the problem or will that just be a bandaid on a larger problem? This type of solution can make women even bigger targets to men with unhealed masculine energy. If companies want to see an increase in applicants that are women, then they need to make these environments safe and friendly for women.
message2: A fair hiring process takes into consideration the fact that we do not live in a meritocracy. Given that the judging of candidates will most likely be performed by those who have privilege and access to resources that most women do not, judging the candidates on the exact same basis as one another without taking these disparities into consideration would lead to an unbalanced hiring process. In other words, there is no such thing as a truly "blind" hiring process; the most we can aim for is a fair one - not to mention considering the enhancements to the field the additional viewpoints a women's lived experience can bring.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: Yes it has been overblown.  The media has portrayed these incidents to be much more common than they actually are, which has fueled the public reaction to be greater than necessary.  The public reaction has largely overlooked the fact that the majority of these incidents have been started with a suspect resisting a lawful arrest.  It has focused almost exclusively on the officer's actions and ignored the fact that nothing detrimental would have occurred had the suspect complied with the officer's orders.  There has also been rioting and destruction by some in the public that has not accomplished anything positive.  Another overreaction is in the public's call for an immediate termination or filing of criminal charges against an officer when there has not been adequate time to conduct a thorough investigation of the officer's actions.

seedtext: The process includes a thorough investigation before any kind of restraint or arrest of a person. This society's legal process has a basic tenet of innocent until [proven guilty. The college must treat everyone fairly and react strongly only when there is good cause to do so. To immediately act is to assume the accusation is true. The accuser could have a grudge against the accused and just made it up or maybe a past wrong by the accused against wasn't righted and the accuser did it out of spite. We need to be logical, not driven by emotions, gather evidence and listen to all sides, then decide on a course of action.
message1: Our society's legal process of "innocent until proven guilty" only applies to legal punishment such as incarceration (removal of one's constitutional right to freedom) and not to access to particular areas or private institutions. The university can make its own decisions about who is allowed on its campus, so this is not an area where "innocent until proven guilty applies." The reality is that universities far more often dismiss accusations such as this and protect the people who committed the sexual assault in order to maintain their reputation. We should be protecting the victim of the assault, not the perpetrator and certainly not the university's reputation.
message2: Many study have indicated that most of allegation about sexual harassments are correct. issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: While I am supportive of an increase in representation of women in math, sciences, and engineering, I do not believe the best method of achieving this is to give blanket priority to female graduates over male graduates. There is no doubt that women have historically been under-represented in fields such as math and engineering, however by giving women graduates a priority over men simply because of the fact they are women could lead to less-talented candidates entering the field. This is simply not true.  Think about how many times you have seen officers acting inappropriately on the news.  Compare that to 400,000 each day.  The numbers just dont support this narrative. message1: I agree with your statement that since there are 400,000 estimated police interactions per day, that the number of interactions where there is brutality or an overreaction by the police to a minority crime suspect is low. However, we can not dismiss how serious these interactions, no matter how few or infrequent, are to society as a whole. The question is about people's reaction to the problem, and for me, it will never be "overblown" until it is resolved. Many police officers are afraid of minority suspects, even though they are loathe to admit it. Police are quicker to move to violence or to draw their gun or to expect resistance. There needs to be additional training in dealing with minority suspects so that the actions of the police are more in line with how they react to non-minority suspects.
message2: I just think that even one example of this -- especially when it's caught on video -- is one example too many. Police officers have an incredibly important job, and they need both the proper training and the proper demeanor to do it. The altercations we see on the news speak to the need for broader reforms in the policing industry, with more emphasis on deescalation and less on lethal force, and more comprehensive psychological screenings for potential and current officers. We also need to look at police culture -- I agree with you that the issue is a relatively small number of cops who shouldn't be cops, but in most cases, the department knows about and protects those bad apples instead of dealing with them. Protecting the worst among them taints the entire profession. If good cops could speak out against bad ones without fear of retaliation, the system would function better and we'd all be better off. And perhaps we should stop relying on police officers to handle situations they're not trained or prepared for, like acute mental crises. Police can't be trained to handle every single situation, so why not have other departments designed to handle the complexities of things like mental-health emergencies? It would take some pressure off officers and help avoid the kinds of stories we see where people end up shot for being mentally ill or autistic, for example.

Police officers should be trained how to properly handle these things and they should expect people to not exactly enjoy being arrested. Meaning that their instinctual response should not be to draw their weapons and fire. Also riots and protests are also no grounds to shoot your own citizenry, but instead one should look at the *reason* people are protesting or rioting in the first place. Their is always something wrong that is making people upset. The response should not be to attack them as that would only make them more upset and solve nothing. I do agree with your last point that people are quick to call for termination before a thorough investigation, but the officer should be suspended and not allowed to work during the mean time. Also, take note of the fact that a police force investigating itself is heavily biased in their own favor and will usually turn up that the officer committed no crime. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.
message1: I agree with aspects of this point of view, especially with the points made about the rights of the accused versus the rights of victims. There seems to a lot of pressure from society to reject the claims of innocence from an accused person, which is not exactly fair. However, the point remains that safety must be maintained, so it is up to the discretion of the university to determine the course of action while an investigation is performed. However, a person should not be dismissed permanently simply because they have been accused.
message2: While I agree that in our judicial system, the rights of the accused are very important and the accused should not be found guilty without a fair trial, a university is not a court of law.  A university, as an institution, has an obligation to protect the safety and well being of its students.  Especially given how incredibly rare false accusations of rape or sexual assault are, I believe the university has an obligation to act to remove the person accused of rape or sexual assault in order to protect the safety and emotional well being of the victim.  To do otherwise is to create an unsafe environment for the victim and to fail in its obligation to protect the safety and well being of students.  In the highly unlikely event that the accused person is found not to have committed the rape or sexual assault (and that's seriously highly unlikely given how rare false accusations are and how its far more likely that rapists and sexual assaulters get away with their crimes than for false accusations to happen) the falsely accused individual can then be allowed back to campus and have their tuition refunded for the time that they were not allowed to attend.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Having someone immediately removed from a campus just because someone made an accusation against them is a little ridiculous. This fear would come from knowing that if they say the wrong thing or act the wrong way they could be taken off campus without proof. Now if there is immediate proof then I completely agree that they should be kicked out, however without a good amount of evidence to prove something happened then I think kicking the students off campus should wait.
message1: Not kicking the person off campus creates an even greater fear - the fear that someone can assault you and be allowed to be near you during the investigation. It's ridiculous to leave an accused assaulter around the victim. Not only is it traumatic, it allows the assaulter to potentially threaten the victim further.
message2: There are pros and cons to immediate removal. On the one hand it does presume guilt prior to an examination of the evidence. On the other hand, false accusations are rare. A better solution may be to suspend the accused with the idea that this is for their safety as well, while the incident is investigated.

issuetext: The United States should invest greater economic, military, and human resources in fighting the spread of ISIS and similar organizations around the world.
seedtext: ISIS and other terrorist organizations can be extremely dangerous- they threaten democratic values and the safety of our country. Because of this, the US should make sure that there is enough resources going to combat this dangerous organization. Without putting in resources to combat ISIS and similar organizations, US citizens could be at risk. It is important that the government helps protect its' citizens against the agenda of ISIS. It is important that the government is paying attention to what is happening so that they can help its citizens. Otherwise, democracy and the safety of citizens in the US would be at stake.
message1: Terrorist attacks cause very few deaths in the US compared to other causes. Suicide, car accidents, and homicide kill tens of thousands each. Terrorism is usually exaggerated by the media and government to promote their political goals. It was actions supposedly against terrorism, like the invasion of Iraq, that caused ISIS to form in the first place. The US should only oppose these groups indirectly and carefully, without causing wars or funding opposition groups.
message2: While I agree that ISIS and other terrorist organizations are dangerous and should be dealt with, I don't think the US should continue to invest more and more resources into doing so. Terrorism has often been used as an excuse for modern colonialism, allowing the US to invade countries for political and economic gain. Plus, the US should invest much more of its resources into domestic social programs, like healthcare and housing. The military receives billions of dollars each year, while poverty and homelessness continue to rise domestically. So yes, I do think that it's worth investing in the military in order to protect democracy at home and abroad, but I think the amount we invest in military versus domestic programs is worth reevaluating.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: I completely disagree with this statement. First, reporting about the loss of a life is never overblown. Second we know, and have seen through body cameras and cell phone video, that there is a problem with the way law enforcement interacts with people of color. In fact, people of color are more likely to experience excessive use of force than their white counterparts. This is even true in similar instances. This is not to say that all law enforcement is bad. In fact most law enforcement is here to serve and protect. However, it does point to cultural issues within the institution that must be addressed to restore trust between the groups.
message1: I agree that systematic changes need to be made, but so far there have been none I've heard that would result in a solution to this issue. I also don't agree with the rioting and looting that the US experienced in 2020 and other times in history. issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: Yes it has been overblown.  The media has portrayed these incidents to be much more common than they actually are, which has fueled the public reaction to be greater than necessary.  The public reaction has largely overlooked the fact that the majority of these incidents have been started with a suspect resisting a lawful arrest.  It has focused almost exclusively on the officer's actions and ignored the fact that nothing detrimental would have occurred had the suspect complied with the officer's orders.  There has also been rioting and destruction by some in the public that has not accomplished anything positive.  Another overreaction is in the public's call for an immediate termination or filing of criminal charges against an officer when there has not been adequate time to conduct a thorough investigation of the officer's actions.
message1: Look, I'm a minority. Officers shouldn't be using any kind of brute force that would put lives in danger; and if they weren't, we probably wouldn't be having this conversation. The difference isn't that they aren't more common in media than in real life--it's that now they're recorded, so we catch them more often. And we should! The institution of police is in a unique position to have physical power over the people they pledge to protect, so they shouldn't be getting caught up in brutality scandals, should they? As for rioting, rioting is a small cry compared to what minorities have to face against that brutality. It's not just excessive force that leads to death. It's also profiling, excessive force in general, and prison time for crimes white people disproportionately get away with.   If a cop's involved with someone dying, I don't see why we can't suspend them while an investigation occurs.
message2: Time and time again, there have been incidents of blatant police brutality, and several in the last few years. One prime example is murder of George Floyd where police officer Derek Chauvin, a 44 year old white police office was filmed kneeling on his neck for over 9 minutes, while he was handcuffed, lying face-down in the street, while fellow officers watched. This case alone should be enough to show that yes, there definitely is reason for extreme public reaction and outrage.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
