issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: To immediately remove someone who has been accused of a crime is against their rights. You cannot place judgement until proof is given, an accusation alone is not enough and is unfair to all involved. It would be better for the accuser to remove themselves until it is proven to be true. If someone is accused of assault and then forcibly removed, and after that they are proven innocent, they definitely have a case to sue against the establishment.
message1: Everything you have said, while very valid, can also be said of the accuser. They also have a right to a safe environment, as they have paid their tution, just as the accused. If someone accused of assault is allowed to remain on campus, and then that person assaults someone else, or threatens and intimidates the accuser, the establishment would also be in danger of a lawsuit. Imagine someone is thought to have committed a murder. Who would feel comfortable with that person living somewhere like a college campus until they are proven guilty or innocent? Perhaps we might agree that both the accuser and the accused be removed from campus for the safety of them both.
message2: However, if you don't remove someone and they turn out to be guilty later, you've given them a chance to continue or even escalate their crimes. In order to be fair, you should remove them and investigate and if the report turns out to be false, you permanently remove (expel) the person that made the false report. That way, you protect victims and also discourage false reporting as a revenge tactic. You don't want to be the cause of additional crimes by hesitating.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: Women have been historically underrepresented in the fields of math, science and engineering. For a good part of the 20th century, women weren't admitted into advanced University programs in these disciplines. The only way to correct this under- representation is to give priority to qualified women in hiring decisions. This presupposes that male and female candidates are equally qualified. There may be political discussion about unfair affirmative action, but there is no other viable way to correct the historical imbalance.
message1: What is the definition of equally qualified ?  If both candidates are equally qualified, wouldn't hire systematically someone over the other based on traits that they can not change be unfair ?  Would it be actually fair to counter an injustice with another ?  Restoring equality should be done based solely on qualifications and skills (that a person can work on) rather than inherited physical traits that they can not change. This is especially more important in the STEM field where brain matters more than physical traits
message2: Women want to have equal rights.  The only way to have equal rights is for the best person to receive the job.  Women should not get special treatment for a job, just because they are a woman. The same goes for any gender. The merits of the person should help them get a job, not their gender.

message1: I definitely see your point of view and agree with some of what you said, but there are other factors to consider. We live in a patriarchal society and that needs to be taken into consideration. But I do agree with the whole removing names/identifying info from the resume, that could work.
message2: Removing gender-identifying language from hiring documents would perpetuate the disparity. The perception that a preferential hiring decision somehow taints the quality of the candidate is a social problem. Men have enjoyed the benefits of preference for decades if not centuries. The real question is how we determine what is balanced and equitable in the mix between men and women. There are times when policy must nudge society in a  more equitable direction than neutral evaluation of data allows.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.

Where we differ is that I do not agree that women shouldn't get priority in hiring decisions especially when companies have an obvious lack of women working there. You even admitted that there is an obvious lack of women in STEM and it is unfair. When something is unfair then as a society we should do what we can to level the playing field.
message2: I totally agree with a lot of the arguments and support that you've given regarding giving women priority when hiring for STEM jobs. I think you have an interesting idea about balancing out the hiring committee so that it's a more even split between men and women… which would theoretically result in a more even hiring of men and women. But I wonder if that would help with the hiring of females, especially if there is already more men than women that work at the company. I think in addition to adjusting the hiring committee, there should be some sort of goal that hiring committees can work towards, regarding the ratio of men to women within the overall workplace.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.
message1: While I agree that in our judicial system, the rights of the accused are very important and the accused should not be found guilty without a fair trial, a university is not a court of law.  A university, as an institution, has an obligation to protect the safety and well being of its students.  Especially given how incredibly rare false accusations of rape or sexual assault are, the university has an obligation to act to remove the person accused of rape or sexual assault in order to protect the safety and emotional well being of the victim.  To do otherwise is to create an unsafe environment for the victim and to fail in its obligation to protect the safety and well being of students.  In the highly unlikely event that the accused person is found not to have committed the rape or sexual assault (and that's seriously highly unlikely given how rare false accusations are and how its far more likely that rapists and sexual assaulters get away with their crimes than for false accusations to happen) the falsely accused individual can then be allowed back to campus and have their tuition refunded for the time that they were not allowed to attend.
message2: I agree that victims should be believed and that they are deserving of protection, but I disagree with the accused not facing any consequences. While I am hesitantly in support of removing the student, I do think restraining orders or something protective would be a good way for the accused student to remain, but also a good way for the victim to feel comfortable.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: Yes it has been overblown.  The media has portrayed these incidents to be much more common than they actually are, which has fueled the public reaction to be greater than necessary.  The public reaction has largely overlooked the fact that the majority of these incidents have been started with a suspect resisting a lawful arrest.  It has focused almost exclusively on the officer's actions and ignored the fact that nothing detrimental would have occurred had the suspect complied with the officer's orders.  There has also been rioting and destruction by some in the public that has not accomplished anything positive.  Another overreaction is in the public's call for an immediate termination or filing of criminal charges against an officer when there has not been adequate time to conduct a thorough investigation of the officer's actions.
message1: Actually, I believe the public's reaction has been due to the fact that it has rarely been given proper attention to. The select incidents that have been televised actually show proof of harm being done to a human being. Perhaps the human being "persecuted" (not "prosecuted") by a police officer is outrageous to those of us who value human life. It is not a police officer's place to decide the extent of punishment that a criminal should receive. Especially, not a single officer or even a crew. All criminals are making a wrong choice, that is obvious. It is a police officer's duty to simply stop them, and bring them into custody. Resisting arrest is certainly going to make it harder for the police officer, but they should be solving that problem by taking less drastic measures before considering a lethal ending. The court system and the government officials can put their many heads together to decide the punishment for that criminal. Simply breaking the law is not reason enough to take someone's life. Even mass murderers, school shooters, and serial killers get handcuffed  and taken into the police station for questioning while being handed food and drink to satiate them.
message2: Though not all (or even most) of these incidents involve resisting arrest, let's concede that point. Let's suppose these people are resisting arrest. Does this justify the shootings? Just because someone resists arrest does not mean that an officer is justified in shooting the person. Furthermore, it needs to be examined what constitutes "resisting arrest", because there are some officers that are inclined to say someone is resisting if a person, for example, recoils when rough-handled or perhaps take a few steps back or away out of fear or adrenaline. Police officers should be trained how to properly handle these things and they should expect people to not exactly enjoy being arrested. Meaning that their instinctual response should not be to draw their weapons and fire. Also riots and protests are also no grounds to shoot your own citizenry, but instead one should look at the *reason* people are protesting or rioting in the first place. Their is always something wrong that is making people upset. The response should not be to attack them as that would only make them more upset and solve nothing. I do agree with your last point that people are quick to call for termination before a thorough investigation, but the officer should be suspended and not allowed to work during the mean time. Also, take note of the fact that a police force investigating itself is heavily biased in their own favor and will usually turn up that the officer committed no crime. The investigations should be done by an outside party.

Like in any profession you have some police officers that should not be police officers and sometimes they act like criminals.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: As a woman in STEM, my primary consideration is feeling that I have a fair shot at any position that a man has. I don't expect any preferential treatment or gender-based affirmative action policies to compensate for past gender discrimination in STEM, though. I wouldn't want there to be any doubts about my suitability for the position due to my merit, rather than my gender. message1: I see your point and I totally agree with you. I think women should be hired based on their own abilities rather than external factors such as their gender, race, ethnicity, and etc. But I think depends on the situation, the quota policy can be helpful. I believe having a quota will help to reinforce the idea of women have fair position in STEM. This is only a starting point. Because as you said, people may have unconscious biases against women in STEM, if they work in HR, they may skip applications of female applicants. Having a quota will enforce these people to look through every application. But I do admit that there's a con with having a quota which is women are not competing with men but women for the quota when looking for job, but I still feel like the quota is a very good starting point for eradicating (hopefully) gender biases, and once it becomes a norm, company can put out other hiring policies.
message2: I think the term "affirmative action" often comes with a lot of baggage and it is misunderstood, so I agree with you that programs that further perpetuate a gender divide are not good. However, I think the term or these policies can be applied more broadly. For example, what you suggested of having a diverse hiring panel could be considered a form of affirmative action. I agree that if any of these policies are to be implemented, they should be done carefully so as to not make individuals feel that they are being hired to feel a quote, as opposed to being hired for their qualifications. However, I acknowledge that, as a man, I am one step removed from this and that the voices of women should be just as equally heard. I think the main goal of any affirmative action program is to ensure that those who are qualified (whether they be women or men) are all considered and given a fair chance.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.
message1: The rights of the accused are important as well. The victim should be protected as much as possible. The removal of the accused from the campus is a step in the right direction. The situation needs to be solved as quickly as possible.
message2: I have read your statement and I agree with your point of view.  Our country is based on the idea a person is innocent until proven guilty but a sexual assault must be handled carefully. The victim should not have to be exposed to the accused in classroom or social settings. It is also extremely important to not violate the victim with ignoring the accusation.

One reason could be prejudice - specifically, holding steadfast to generalized "soft skill" attributes of the female population. Those who are proponents of breaking down these barriers recommend prioritizing women in the hiring decision of STEM careers. These women would still be expected to complete their relevant degree, but in supporting affirmative action, it would change the playing field significantly.

For far too long certain groups have been underrepresented, but I think we can solve that without punishing men.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: Yes it has been overblown.  The media has portrayed these incidents to be much more common than they actually are, which has fueled the public reaction to be greater than necessary. It has focused almost exclusively on the officer's actions and ignored the fact that nothing detrimental would have occurred had the suspect complied with the officer's orders.  There has also been rioting and destruction by some in the public that has not accomplished anything positive.  Another overreaction is in the public's call for an immediate termination or filing of criminal charges against an officer when there has not been adequate time to conduct a thorough investigation of the officer's actions.

message2: This response ignores the many times officers used excessive force to deal with suspects resisting arrest, or the seriousness of the crimes supposedly being committed. Not to mention, you provide no examples.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: Historically, women have not had access to higher education, and for those women that do, sexism has oftentimes prohibited them from getting well-paid positions. It has proved to be difficult for women to be in these environments, due to less female-friendly work environments and more stories of sexual assault. In order to increase representation and make these workplaces more equitable, women with relevant degrees should be given priority over men.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: As a woman in STEM, my primary consideration is feeling that I have a fair shot at any position that a man has. There's a perception in some workplaces with these policies that women were only hired to fill a quota, perpetuating the gender divide. I wouldn't want there to be any doubts about my suitability for the position due to my merit, rather than my gender. Of course, people who hire for STEM positions may have unconscious (or conscious) gender biases, but I think that having a diverse hiring panel would be a better policy than implementing gender quotas.

seedtext: While ISIS is simply a symptom of a larger problem plaguing countries in the middle east, their existence provides no value to the region or the world in any way. The United States should not lose sight of the hard fought gains in countries like Iraq and continue to support governments that are fighting ISIS on the ground whether that be through logistical, financial or military means. Groups like ISIS need to be quickly and swiftly destroyed to prevent their actions and if done swiftly enough discourage other similar groups from forming in the future.
message1: I agree with you that the US should definitely act to prevent the influence of groups like ISIS, but I don't think that the US should always work to "quickly and swiftly destroy" these groups, generally speaking.  My opinion is that confronting these groups in military fashion can involve huge costs in dollars and military lives, and risks larger wars and conflicts and alienating our allies.  I think you're right that it's a good idea that we should combat these groups, but we should do so on many fronts, including education, aid, diplomacy and military action as a last resort.
message2: While I agree that ISIS seems to bring nothing good to the table when it comes to the development of the countries where they are present, and to us their interpretation of Islam is egregious, who are we to decide whether these people get to operate, live and die?  Why does the United States get to decide something that the citizens of that country should decide?  If they call for military aid in combatting ISIS, I would consider giving it to them; but just systematically destroying ISIS because we disagree with their practices and doctrine is arrogant, foolhardy, and against the very principles that we have founded our country upon.

issuetext: The United States should invest greater economic, military, and human resources in fighting the spread of ISIS and similar organizations around the world.
seedtext: ISIS and other terrorist organizations can be extremely dangerous- they threaten democratic values and the safety of our country. Because of this, the US should make sure that there is enough resources going to combat this dangerous organization. Without putting in resources to combat ISIS and similar organizations, US citizens could be at risk. It is important that the government helps protect its' citizens against the agenda of ISIS. It is important that the government is paying attention to what is happening so that they can help its citizens. Otherwise, democracy and the safety of citizens in the US would be at stake.
message1: Terrorist attacks can be serious when they happen, but they cause very few deaths in the US compared to other causes. Suicide, car accidents, and homicide kill tens of thousands each. Terrorism can be exaggerated by the media and government to promote their political goals. It was actions supposedly against terrorism, like the invasion of Iraq, that likely caused ISIS to form in the first place. To protect Democracy and security, the US should probably oppose these groups indirectly and carefully, without causing wars or funding opposition groups. We could always look at the evidence and see which approaches create the best results.
message2: Without guns, there cannot be any war. Money should be spent on trying to get rid of violence, not supporting it with the same. This money could be better spent elsewhere.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: I believe women are underrepresented in the workplace in general, so they deserve special treatment. Of course, choosing a woman over a man should only happen if they have the same qualifications, or if the woman is more qualified. Women historically have not had the same rights in the workplace as men, and now is a good time to make up for that. By hiring more women, social stigmas and stereotypes might disappear as well. It is important to show society that women can do more than just stay at home and cook.
message1: Studies have shown the absence of the mother in the home, raising their children, has negative social, economical, and moral repercussions. Children are no longer taught their family’s values and traditions, leading to higher crime rates, sexual immorality, drug use, and poor economic status.
message2: I do not believe that men applying for jobs should be penalized for a lack of women being represented in the workplace.    I believe the best candidate for the job should be hired regardless of their gender.    Picking a woman over a man for a position only because of her gender is discrimination against the other people who are applying for the position. This can have real world ramifications. An example is a man who is the sole provider for his family isn't considered for the job based only on his gender.

issuetext: The United States should invest greater economic, military, and human resources in fighting the spread of ISIS and similar organizations around the world.
seedtext: The USA should invest more resources to combatting the spread of ISIS and other similar organizations throughout the world. ISIS is a terrorist organization and promotes violence amongst innocents. They have been known to brutally slaughter men women and Children. The US are the ones with the ability to stop them. This is because of their great power. The US needs to do this. ISIS cannot spread further and further.
message1: The US already spends enough on stopping ISIS. In fact I don't even remember the last time I heard about an ISIS attack. The US spends more than enough on combatting this group. I am more worried about domestic terrorists than I am ISIS. That is where the US needs to spend more on.
message2: Understandably, we should all be against organizations who brutally slaughter men, women, and children. ISIS and similar organization's are horrible. However, we live in a country where extremist groups are not tolerated and against the law. We need to focus on protecting our citizens internally and externally before we go to another country and take on their fight. We need to be wise and peaceful, so we can avoid unnecessary escalations that can cause more harm to our citizens and country in the long run.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: Women have been historically underrepresented in the fields of math, science and engineering. For a good part of the 20th century, women weren't admitted into advanced University programs in these disciplines. The only way to correct this under- representation is to give priority to qualified women in hiring decisions. This presupposes that male and female candidates are equally qualified. There may be political discussion about unfair affirmative action, but there is no other viable way to correct the historical imbalance.
message1: I agree that women have been historically underrepresented in the fields of Math, science, and engineering. This is a problem that we should strive to correct by not discriminating based on gender. I believe that giving women priority in hiring decisions would be step backward because we would still be discriminating based on gender. The only way to correct historical injustice is to no longer follow the same practices.
message2: I agree to a point - women have been historically disadvantaged in the field of math, science, and engineering. However, history is exactly that - in the past. Women no longer have to put up with job discrimination. Giving women first dibs at a job, so to speak, is like repeating history, this time by putting qualified men at a disadvantage. At some point we have to learn from history and not repeat it.

message1: There actually is a way to increase representation of women in math and science fields and it isn't through just giving women a job over a more qualified man. This is incredibly unfair. The best way to increase representation of women in math and science fields is to interview more women than men - to open the field up more- to make sure that the best candidate is selected. It is not right to hire a woman over a man who is a better fit (more qualified or however else that is defined) to simply fulfill a quota. I even hold this opinion as a woman who studied Biology in college and hold a Master's degree in a science field as well.
message2: This is a weak argument because it only works in theory. There will never be two equal candidates, one will always have a strength or weakness the other may not have. The best person for the job should always be hired, that can be due to qualifications or just a better fit for the team. Typically in these fields soft skills are lacking. The solution would be continue to push women in to STEM fields. Among older populations there is generally less interest in STEM but as the population gets younger, there is more of an interest. The gap is not due to sexism (on a large scale) but the amount of women who have worked to be in these fields. This number will only continue to grow as the younger population moves in.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: As a woman in STEM, my primary consideration is feeling that I have a fair shot at any position that a man has. There's a perception in some workplaces with these policies that women were only hired to fill a quota, perpetuating the gender divide. I wouldn't want there to be any doubts about my suitability for the position due to my merit, rather than my gender. Of course, people who hire for STEM positions may have unconscious (or conscious) gender biases, but I think that having a diverse hiring panel would be a better policy than implementing gender quotas.
message1: Women are as capable as men in STEM. I fully understand your concerns and I hope this unconscious gender biases may slowly disappear. message2: I completely agree with you. I think that would be a good solution that ensures companies hire the best candidate as opposed to trying to fulfill a quota.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: Historically, women have not had access to higher education, and for those women that do, sexism has oftentimes prohibited them from getting well-paid positions. Math, sciences, and engineering has historically been a male-dominated field. It has proved to be difficult for women to be in these environments, due to less female-friendly work environments and more stories of sexual assault. In addition, hiring decisions make it less likely that male-dominated spaces would hire a woman with similar credentials to a man. In order to increase representation and make these workplaces more equitable, women with relevant degrees should be given priority over men.
message1: I see your point and think that it is important to give equal consideration to everyone who is qualified for a position. message2: I would rather see blind hiring of the best person possible. I feel if this was used instead of just giving women priority you would soon see more women in the field without having to block a good candidate for the job because it was a man.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.

message1: While I agree it is important to encourage women to pursue whatever field of study and profession they like, I don't believe women should be given priority while being hired solely because they are women. This could lead to people questioning their ability because it brings up the idea they were hired just because they are a woman instead of having the best qualifications and experience.  It is also not entirely possible to know if men were mistaken for physicians just because they were men unless it was explicitly noted. It could have just been an honest mistake.
message2: The above response does not indicate whether there is an agreement to giving women priority over men in hiring decisions.  I strongly disagree with giving women priority.  Sure, let's impower women by stomping all over the supposed "equality" that we're all striving so very hard to achieve.  How is giving women special treatment equality?  Answer: it isn't.  Let's focus on empowering women in male dominated fields in ways that are truly bringing attention to what it means to be on equal footing. issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: The whole point of feminism is so that both women, men, and any other genders are treated as equals. Do I think there's a huge lack of women in STEM? Yes. Is there very likely sexism going on during hiring as it stands now? Oh yeah, definitely. I just don't ideologically agree with blanket boosting a woman's chance at hiring for simply being a women. Something like requiring a gender balance on the hiring committee like half male half female so the candidate receives a relatively more fair and balanced interview.
message1: I agree that we should not favor women just because they are women. I think everyone should earn their job position based on their academic and career achievement. Now, I also believe that women should have more support than the average men when it comes to entering the career and overcome the ongoing discrimination in the STEM field.
message2: I agree the point of feminism is make society more equitable for all genders and creating a hiring preference for women is artificial. However, you stated there is sexism in hiring decisions, which I would suggest is also artificial. I think we can both agree that removing sexism so women with the skills and qualifications can contribute to STEM careers would be best, but we haven't eliminated sexism. I think you are searching for something more defined, as opposed to just a blanket concept. Having gender balances on the hiring committee is a tool that can work to resolve this disparity, but who hires the hiring committee?

While I do not feel as though we should be entirely reactionary in our response to national security, I feel as though we are neglecting more pressing matters. The billions of dollars that we spend on our military have made us a global superpower, but we are not at war with other nations, we are at war with ideals. Nations and governments rise and fall, but ideals can live on indefinitely. While in the past, when the world faced such crises as the rise of Nazis or Communism, we needed to pour as much money as possible towards fighting these evils; however this is no longer the case. War as a whole has changed. Wars are no longer fought on battlefields with uniformed nations against one another. Wars are waged against organizations of loosely networked radicals. As long as an extremist has a heartbeat, their warped views will inevitably live on to be passed on to whoever they can proselytize to. The rise, fall, and subsequent resurrection of civilian-led terrorist organizations such as ISIS and the Taliban have proved this. I do agree that the money we have invested into our military has helped many people in other countries, as we have been able to protect innocent lives in countries where the government has collapsed, such as in Iraq and Afghanistan. Our military has helped many people live more prosperous lives and has brought democracy to places that would have never been seen otherwise. issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.

It has focused almost exclusively on the officer's actions and ignored the fact that nothing detrimental would have occurred had the suspect complied with the officer's orders.  There has also been rioting and destruction by some in the public that has not accomplished anything positive.  Another overreaction is in the public's call for an immediate termination or filing of criminal charges against an officer when there has not been adequate time to conduct a thorough investigation of the officer's actions.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: While I am supportive of an increase in representation of women in math, sciences, and engineering, I do not believe the best method of achieving this is to give blanket priority to female graduates over male graduates. There is no doubt that women have historically been under-represented in fields such as math and engineering, however by giving women graduates a priority over men simply because of the fact they are women could lead to less-talented candidates entering the field. I believe a better method would be to simply look at the resume/qualifications of the candidate and choose based off of who is more qualified, therefore leading to a "blind" and more objective hiring process.
message1: I agree with this person that the system needs to hire in a more fair manner than just giving blanket priority of one group over the other. There needs to be a way to eliminate bias and by only looking at qualifications may be the right thing to do here. There also needs to be a personality assessment and I'm not sure how that can be done blindly.
message2: A fair hiring process takes into consideration the fact that we do not live in a meritocracy. Given that the judging of candidates will most likely be performed by those who have privilege and access to resources that most women do not, judging the candidates on the exact same basis as one another without taking these disparities into consideration would lead to an unbalanced hiring process. In other words, there is no such thing as a truly "blind" hiring process; the most we can aim for is a fair one - not to mention considering the enhancements to the field the additional viewpoints a women's lived experience can bring.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.
message1: I agree with the statements this person made, but I'm not sure it is the best route to take. In cases of sexual assault I believe the victim and perpetrator should be separated. Until the case is closed or investigated, the perpetrator should be removed from campus. There is a greater chance of another sexual assault or other upsetting interactions for the victim if they ran into the perpetrator on campus. Victims of sexual assault want to feel protected by the institution and more importantly the police. I place their experience and comfortability ahead of anyone else in this scenario.
message2: I agree that everyone has the right of presumed innocence when convicted of crimes, even if those crimes are significant.  Protection of the victims is also of the utmost importance when handling a violent crime, especially from retribution and harassment by the perpetrator.  In the case of a college campus, where the victim's schedule may keep them in potential proximity to their attacker, there must be some protocol in place to allow them to continue their studies in safety.  Whether that is house arrest for the attacker, orders of protection, or another method is dependent on extenuating circumstances.

Giving them a leg up is only fair BUT only if they meet the qualifications of the position. This may be the best way to ensure an equal number of qualified women are hired rather than hiring by chance.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: Historically, women have not had access to higher education, and for those women that do, sexism has oftentimes prohibited them from getting well-paid positions. Math, sciences, and engineering has historically been a male-dominated field. It has proved to be difficult for women to be in these environments, due to less female-friendly work environments and more stories of sexual assault. In addition, hiring decisions make it less likely that male-dominated spaces would hire a woman with similar credentials to a man. In order to increase representation and make these workplaces more equitable, women with relevant degrees should be given priority over men.
message1: I can completely understand your point of view however I respectfully disagree. Women have fought very hard for equality and giving us a leg up isn't equal treatment. Perhaps people in the STEM industry should be hired completely on their qualifications rather than their gender. If we could take gender completely off of the resume that would be the most fair and equal way to hire someone.
message2: I believe that the most qualified person for any given position is the one that should be hired. Women now outnumber men on college campuses. Women are able to study and work in the field of their choice. Women should be expected to meet the same academic and professional standards as men. I do not believe that hiring quotas are necessary.

issuetext: The United States should invest greater economic, military, and human resources in fighting the spread of ISIS and similar organizations around the world.
seedtext: The USA should invest more resources to combatting the spread of ISIS and other similar organizations throughout the world. ISIS is a terrorist organization and promotes violence amongst innocents. They have been known to brutally slaughter men women and Children. The US are the ones with the ability to stop them. This is because of their great power. The US needs to do this. ISIS cannot spread further and further.
message1: I agree that ISIS is a threat that we should be concerned about, but I do not support increasing funding or manpower to fight it. We have had troops in the Middle East for years and they have returned with nothing to show for it. People are dying on both sides and the war still continues. The US is powerful, but so is ISIS.
message2: I understand your point, but I will pose you two questions: Why should the USA have to invest more resources to stop ISIS? Why are we always responsible for the well-being of the entire world, when we are only demonized and made fun of in return? These are important questions that are consistently overlooked in these types of topics. Such things as ISIS do not currently pose a direct threat to us, nor is it our duty to protect the weak. The federal government should be prioritizing the needs of its OWN citizens. By constantly funneling money to other countries, we are taking money that could be used instead to improve the lives of the people in our country. Other countries' threats are not our issue; we need to focus on our own threats.

issuetext: The United States should invest greater economic, military, and human resources in fighting the spread of ISIS and similar organizations around the world.
seedtext: The reason why the United States should invest heavily into military is that if we fall behind the order of the world falls. The United States is preventing countries like Russia and China from taking over other countries. As long as the United States is a top military power, it is unlikely for another world war to happen anytime soon. The United States is what is preventing other countries from dominance in the world.
message1: While it is true that the United States is a top military power, that alone will not prevent any upcoming world wars. United States alone cannot prevent world wars and this is evident from the past world war. The United States has already poured countless dollars and funds and effort into the military and the fight against ISIS, to very little results. While military power is important, I believe the United States should put effort and funds into something else besides military power.
message2: The assumption that the United States should be the overall ruling power in the world is one that is taught to children and citizens of the United States. Just as much, the vilification of other countries, such as China and Russia, is also taught and propagandized to support this initial assumption. The world is not going to suddenly just fall apart if the United States is no longer the single ruling global superpower. I agree that the United States should retain power globally, and to do this the United States should follow suit and invest heavily in education (like other countries have done), which has a longer-lasting effect and creates natural development (including global influence) within a country. The greater a country's educational system, the more power they accrue within the global sphere over time due to advances in technology and science.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.
message1: I see your point and I understand where you are coming from. However, this I believe is also for the good of the accused as well as the accuser. What if sympathizers of the accused decide to "teach him/her" a lesson and in the process harm them. I believe the accuser would not want that on their conscience. For both their safety, physical and emotional, respectively, the accuser should be barred from campus until investigations are done.
message2: I agree with aspects of this point of view. There seems to a lot of pressure from society to reject the claims of innocence from an accused person, which is not exactly fair. However, the point remains that safety must be maintained, so it is up to the discretion of the university to determine the course of action while an investigation is performed. However, a person should not be dismissed permanently simply because they have been accused.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: Having someone immediately removed from a campus just because someone made an accusation against them is a little ridiculous. This type of precedent sets up mainly male students but could also set up female students as well to be in a position where they are in constant fear. This fear would come from knowing that if they say the wrong thing or act the wrong way they could be taken off campus without proof. Now if there is immediate proof then I completely agree that they should be kicked out, however without a good amount of evidence to prove something happened then I think kicking the students off campus should wait.
message1: I agree that there should be at least some evidence that the assault took place before the accused is removed from campus. However, in many cases of sexual assault, there is no evidence: no witnesses, no pictures, no audio or video recordings. Therefore, I am in favor of only temporarily removing them from campus while still allowing them to participate in classes remotely until they are found either guilty or not guilty.
message2: If you are suggesting that they be kicked out entirely from the moment a claim is made I would agree. If an accusation is made the one being accused should be put on a temporary hold while the issue is investigated in order to protect the victim.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: Yes it has been overblown.  The media has portrayed these incidents to be much more common than they actually are, which has fueled the public reaction to be greater than necessary.  The public reaction has largely overlooked the fact that the majority of these incidents have been started with a suspect resisting a lawful arrest.  It has focused almost exclusively on the officer's actions and ignored the fact that nothing detrimental would have occurred had the suspect complied with the officer's orders.  There has also been rioting and destruction by some in the public that has not accomplished anything positive.  Another overreaction is in the public's call for an immediate termination or filing of criminal charges against an officer when there has not been adequate time to conduct a thorough investigation of the officer's actions.
message1: The fact that these situations are even occurring is terrible, media coverage or not.  These situations have always occurred but with cell phones readily available, they are coming to light more often now. The destruction and rioting that you reference is not done by protesters, it is done by people who are taking advantage of peaceful protests and using them as an excuse to loot and destroy.  Those rioters do not care about the cause. They give the peaceful protesters a bad name. I believe any officer that has been accused of excessive force or similar should be suspended while the investigation is being done, especially when there is camera footage of the incident.  And, in many cases, there isn't even an investigation happening unless bystanders or family members pursue it by contacting the media and then the police department feels pressured to look into it. Furthermore, the main issue here is being overlooked. These incidents are happening to minorities which is fueling systemic racism.  Not one incident that has been in the media has shown a white person interacting with the police.
message2: I agree I believe that all this is a a conspiracy to take power away from the police. It is really bad because we need the police and they protect us. If we take power out of their hands there’s no telling what kind of crimes will be allowed to commence.

message1: If a person is accused of sexual assault, they should be removed from campus in order to protect the victim and prevent further harm. If the accused is provided with resources to access their college learning and given an adequate place to live during the investigation, they would have no reason to file a lawsuit against the establishment later on.
message2: i dont think it's fair to the victim to force them to remove themselves when they were the one harmed by the situation. more often than not sexual assault accusations are built off truth. i think it is always better to believe the victim and take necessary precautions before dismissing them.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: While I am supportive of an increase in representation of women in math, sciences, and engineering, I do not believe the best method of achieving this is to give blanket priority to female graduates over male graduates. There is no doubt that women have historically been under-represented in fields such as math and engineering, however by giving women graduates a priority over men simply because of the fact they are women could lead to less-talented candidates entering the field. I believe a better method would be to simply look at the resume/qualifications of the candidate and choose based off of who is more qualified, therefore leading to a "blind" and more objective hiring process.
message1: I agree that blind hiring processes should be the standard. However, I believe that it is important to consider the whole person and the culture of the organization when making hiring decisions as well. If there are equally talented men and women, it is important to try to achieve diversity and parity.
message2: I fully agree with everything you have said. Gender should not be on applications, and therefore not considered. Giving women priority will lead to less quality work. That is not to say that women will produce less quality work than men, but that the quality of the candidate will be considered, not the gender.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: I do not feel that any candidate should be given priority in hiring decisions.  If they were given priority, this is essentially discriminating against men.  All hiring decisions should give priority to the best candidate regardless of gender.  Although I am a woman, I would want to get a job based on merit, not simply because I am a woman.  If a woman was given priority, this could lead to a less qualified candidate getting hired.  It could also lead to resentment in the workplace.
message1: This argument assumes that we live in a fair meritocracy. We don't live in such a world. The suggestion that we do is pushed by those who have benefited from such an illusion. It also assumes finding competent members of underrepresented groups is impossible. I disagree. We can fulfill both requirements of competence while increasing diversity and creating a more fair workplace.
message2: I understand how you feel. It sounds like you are concerned about reverse discrimination. Since there is a disparity between men and women in the fields of math, science and engineering, how would you feel about the hiring of women when the candidates for a job are equal between a man and a woman? I think in that case, it would be fair to hire the woman to give women who have worked hard to enter these fields some chance at equality in job hiring. In the past the man applicant has been given the job over women, even when he was less qualified, so I think it is only fair to give the woman the job when the qualifications are equal.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: As a woman in STEM, my primary consideration is feeling that I have a fair shot at any position that a man has. I don't expect any preferential treatment or gender-based affirmative action policies to compensate for past gender discrimination in STEM, though. There's a perception in some workplaces with these policies that women were only hired to fill a quota, perpetuating the gender divide. I wouldn't want there to be any doubts about my suitability for the position due to my merit, rather than my gender. Of course, people who hire for STEM positions may have unconscious (or conscious) gender biases, but I think that having a diverse hiring panel would be a better policy than implementing gender quotas.
message1: I would say something along the lines of, "I can see your point, having a woman be hired over a man, due to past discrimination, would fuel the notion that women aren't as smart, and her hire would be diminished. I don't really know how we would get more women in the position to hire, if there's a preexisting gender gap in the higher ups, and potential bias, be that conscious or not." I would then ask her how she thinks we should solve the potential bias when hiring.
message2: I see your point and I totally agree with you. I think women should be hired based on their own abilities rather than external factors such as their gender, race, ethnicity, and etc. But I think depends on the situation, the quota policy can be helpful. I believe having a quota will help to reinforce the idea of women have fair position in STEM. This is only a starting point. Because as you said, people may have unconscious biases against women in STEM, if they work in HR, they may skip applications of female applicants. Having a quota will enforce these people to look through every application. But I do admit that there's a con with having a quota which is women are not competing with men but women for the quota when looking for job, but I still feel like the quota is a very good starting point for eradicating (hopefully) gender biases, and once it becomes a norm, company can put out other hiring policies.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: Yes it has been overblown.  The media has portrayed these incidents to be much more common than they actually are, which has fueled the public reaction to be greater than necessary. It has focused almost exclusively on the officer's actions and ignored the fact that nothing detrimental would have occurred had the suspect complied with the officer's orders.  There has also been rioting and destruction by some in the public that has not accomplished anything positive.  Another overreaction is in the public's call for an immediate termination or filing of criminal charges against an officer when there has not been adequate time to conduct a thorough investigation of the officer's actions.
message1: I understand that in order for the situation to have been escalated someone had to have done something wrong to start with. the person in question might have been combative but they should not have to lose their life because they came in contact with law enforcement. the deeper issue is that police treat humans like potential quotas and they are always suspicious even if someone does not do anything wrong. this is really the reason why the police need to be held accountable for the things they do wrong.
message2: I understand where you are coming from and truth be told I sort of agree that the reactions can be overblown and the media is just in there for the views. However, I believe we can see things from the view of the victims as well especially how often these issues come up and how the police seem to be targeting blacks, criminals or no. You can put yourself in the shoes of these blacks. How would you feel being asked to comply with police for just existing? It has been going on for far too long and the reactions are sometimes understandable even though they may be fatal.

issuetext: The public reaction to recent confrontations between police and minority crime suspects has been overblown.
seedtext: While there have been some outright excessive force issues, some unfortunately resulting in the death of minorities at the hands of police, I feel that social media has contributed to the problem by repeatedly replaying these incidents while doing nothing to improve dialogue and truly analyze the data on police use of excessive force against minorities.
message1: I understand where you're coming from. But I think, rather than social media overblowing a handful of cases, widespread access to video recordings sheds light onto a previously underreported issue. And the reporting of these incidents is creating new investigation into relations with the police. But groups who benefit from no changes being made (police unions, conservative news organizations, etc.) are hijacking the narrative in a way that serves them best.
message2: I agree that social media has contributed to the general feeling of doing more talking about it than changing it. But social media has also brought to light these problems, ones we wouldn't have known were happening otherwise, and ones that are incredibly important to acknowledge. We've seen consistent evidence that minorities are the victims of unfair treatment and excessive force by the police. Data is just one aspect of how to analyze what's happening, we can see what's happening with our eyes and we can recognize what minorities have faced in our history.

issuetext: When a sexual assault accusation is made on a college campus, the alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus to protect the well-being of the victim.
seedtext: The process includes a thorough investigation before any kind of restraint or arrest of a person. This society's legal process has a basic tenet of innocent until [proven guilty. The college must treat everyone fairly and react strongly only when there is good cause to do so. To immediately act is to assume the accusation is true. The accuser could have a grudge against the accused and just made it up or maybe a past wrong by the accused against wasn't righted and the accuser did it out of spite. We need to be logical, not driven by emotions, gather evidence and listen to all sides, then decide on a course of action.
message1: The amount of real cases versus being accused strongly favor most being real. We should believe the victim and remove the accused.

issuetext: In order to increase the representation of women in math, sciences and engineering, female graduates with relevant degrees should be given priority in hiring decisions over men.
seedtext: The whole point of feminism is so that both women, men, and any other genders are treated as equals. Giving a competitive edge to women for hiring that is not based on job qualifications and skills seems counter productive to the whole point of feminism. Do I think there's a huge lack of women in STEM? Yes. Is there very likely sexism going on during hiring as it stands now? Oh yeah, definitely. I just don't ideologically agree with blanket boosting a woman's chance at hiring for simply being a women. Something like requiring a gender balance on the hiring committee like half male half female so the candidate receives a relatively more fair and balanced interview.
message1: I agree that sexism exists in the STEM field, and women are often downplayed and viewed as incapable or not more intelligent than men. There is a lack of women in STEM because it is a field that men dominate, and women should represent themselves as being treated equally as candidates for a job application.
message2: I totally agree with a lot of the arguments and support that you've given regarding giving women priority when hiring for STEM jobs. I think you have an interesting idea about balancing out the hiring committee so that it's a more even split between men and women… which would theoretically result in a more even hiring of men and women. I wonder if there should be some sort of goal that hiring committees can work towards, regarding the ratio of men to women within the overall workplace.
